title: five brits locked up dubai
story: Five Brits locked up in Dubai with crimes from bounced cheques to f*** off messageBilly Hood, who was locked up for possessing CBD vape oil, is one of several Brits who have been detained in Dubai in Brit football coach Billy Hood was jailed for  years in Dubai over CBD oil in his carByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA British man whose family claim has vanished after being jailed in the UAE is one of several Brits that have been locked up in Dubai this year.Billy Hood was locked up for possessing CBD vape oil and was previously behind bars in one of Dubaiaposs most notorious prisons after being sentenced to  years.His worried family say he has not been in contact with them since he was transferred to a jail in Abu Dhabi. The -year-old football coach, from Ladbroke Grove, West London, was convicted of possession, selling and drug trafficking after police found four small bottles of CBD vape oil in his car. Billy, who has been locked up for nine months, claims a friend left the CBD oil in his car as he dropped him off at the airport. Alfie Cain said Billy was repeatedly beaten for five days straight while officers tried to force him to confess to drug crimes. He said Billy told him he only signed the drug trafficking confession, which was written in Arabic, because officials told him they would stop the abusehe did. Billy is not the only Brit to have been detained in Dubai this year. The Mirror has looked at the cases of other Brits who have been locked up in .  Billy HoodBillyaposs sudden silence has left his family terried as they say he had recently claimed he had compelling evidence which proved he had been framed by police. His heartbroken mum Brenda said her son hasnapost even been able to get in touch with his lawyer, since he was moved to another jail, The Sun reports.Brenda spoke to Radha Stirling, founder and CEO of pressure group Detained in Dubai, about her fears. He’s going through the most stressful time in his entire le and can’t even communicate with his family, his lawyer or the British Embassy. Ms Stirling said the judicial process in the UAE was unpredictable and warned that unexpected delays are commonplace ahead of Billyaposs appeal judgement on November . She said she hopes Billy makes it home in time for Christmas as he did not deserved to be locked up for something he did not do. Luke Tully British chef Luke Tully claims he was thrown in jail for  months in Dubai after police thought a customer booking a table was code for a drugs deal.The chef was working at a restaurant in the city when he was sent a text message by a dealer he knew requesting a table for  people. When the dealer was arrested, police seized his phone and read the message to -year-old Mr Tully, believing the message was code for a drug deal for g of cocaine.The dad-of-four has said police officers threatened to throw him off a balcony unless he “told them where the drugs were” before he was thrown in a cell for more than a year. Mr Tully claims to have spent £, on legal fees and is now back home in Bishop’s Stortford, Hertfordshire, after the case was thrown out when a judge ruled there was not enough evidence. In a message to fellow Brits planning to visit the UAE, he said: “Don’t botheryou value your liberty.” William Norman Meyerhoff British great-grandfather William Norman Meyerhoff, who has dementia, was locked up in Dubai over bounced cheques he said he didnapost write. It was reported last month that the -year-old is set to be released after officials admitted they made aposaposmistakesaposapos.  Meyerhoff, originally from Grimsby, Lincs., was held by officials during a transit stop on a flight bound for Australia in May. His family said he worked in Dubai over a decade ago but never had any issues there, but authorities told him there were  criminal cases against him. The charges relate to cheques ly made in his name by owners of a company he used to work for - which he denies knowledge off. Woman detained for sending aposf*** youapos WhatsApp messageA British woman was detained in Dubai and faced being locked up for two years for sending a aposf*** youapos WhatsApp message to her flatmate earlier this year. The -year-old HR manager was detained as she tried to leave Dubai on January  after her flatmate complained to local police about her offensive message.The pair had reportedly been arguing about the use of their dining room table while working from home during the pandemic. Officers arrested the woman on suspicion of breaking UAE cyber laws, however she was let off with a £ fine, The Sun reports. In February it was reported she was aposrelievedapos to be back at her parentsapos home in Gloucester and ready to move on from the apostraumaticapos episode. Albert DouglasLondoner Albert Douglas, , was incarcerated in Dubai earlier this year over bounced cheques he didn’t write.He was handed a £. million fine after his son Wolfgangaposs company failed in , despite committing no crime and having no role with the firm.  Albert lost an appeal and tried to flee the prison with the help of people smugglers, but he was caught at the border and given a three-year sentence. The long-term expat had a successful business in Dubai and was said to have loved the city until the unfortunate circumstances which landed him in prison.In September, according toDetained in Dubai reports , Albert was admitted to a Dubai hospital for surgery to repair a dislocated shoulder sustained in prison.Comment MORE ON PoliceCrimePrisonsDubai holidays" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: helpful trick remove car windshield
story: Helpful trick to remove from car windshield in seconds and avoid £ fineMotorists shared a viral clip on social media site TikTok which shows how to quickly remove snow from your windscreen and allow the driver to be up and running and a way on their commuteClearing the windscreen after snowfall is always a tough job Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsA genius trick to remove frost from your car in seconds and avoid £ fine has been shared by drivers As temperatures plummet across the country next week and snow is forecast to fall in some parts. Drivers who fail to clear their windscreens before they set off could earn themselves a £ fine and three points on their driving licence. To avoid splashing out on car covers and de-icing solutions, motorists have come up with a novel way of protecting their vehicle. Motorists shared a viral clip on social media site TikTok which shows how to quickly remove snow from your windscreen.  All that is required is an old blanket or towel, which are left on the car overnight. Thy are advised to put it over the windscreen and secure it beneath their wipers to avoid it blowing away during the night. They simply take off the cover in the morning and quickly remove ice and snow which may have fallen during the night. This allows motorists to go on their way with a clear windscreen and the prospect of getting a fine.  Other ways of avoiding snow and ice build-ups include planning your parking in advance. If you park with your front window pointing east, it will catch the sun rising in the morning and mother nature nature will do the hard work de-icing your car for you.The Mirror told of another shortcut to help drivers yesterday when a mum has praised herself for using carpet stain remover to quickly melt frozen windscreens.Angela Hickling shared a video of her wiping the ice off her car windshield using a bottle of Dr Beckmanaposs Carpet Stain Remover.. She told the Daily Record: Iaposm a genius. Get yourself one of these bottles, fill it with warm water and youaposre sorted. No cold hands scraping anymore and it cleans ya window screen to, the brush bit is ideal. Other tips motorists have suggested include putting plastic bags over wing mirrors overnight to avoid removing frost from them in the morning. But there are some aposshortcutsapos motorists should steer clear of, such as clearing a frosted window with boiling water which is likely to could you money in the long term. title: inside abandoned hidden mansion posh
story: Inside abandoned hidden mansion in posh neighbourhood thats up for auction for £.mA forgotten Victorian villa in Cardfs Lisvane suburb called Blair Athol, which once had its own coach house, is set for auction in December with a guide price of £,,The Victorian villa in Cardfs Lisvane suburb is buried amongst overgrown hedges Image: WalesOnline  Rob BrowneByJoanne RidoutRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Nov | commentsAn abandoned mansion hidden away in a posh Welsh neighbourhood is being auctioned for £.million. Most people who pass by the address in Cardfaposs Lisvane suburb have no idea behind the overgrown hedges and wild garden is a vintage Victorian villa called Blair Athol which once had its own coach house. Itaposs deemed important enough to be included in Coflein, the online catalogue of archaeology, buildings, industrial and maritime heritage in Wales.And it is now going to auction for a guide price of £,,, reports Wales Online. The archive site describes the property as being a large brick mansion with a dressed stone entrance facade and fine Victorian veranda, dating back to the late th century and set in its own formal lawns to the front.  A photo of the exterior of the home before it was abandoned to ruin shows off its grandeur with a columned ground-floor veranda and balcony above it allowing for views across the city. The basic infrastructure is still largely intact, albeit the views obscured, but the interior paints a far more tragic picture. Graffiti on the walls and bordered up stained glass windows suffocate the glamorous urban mansion, while some of its period features, including fire places and a staircase appear to have been replaced.  But what the property does boast is plenty of space, including a number of basement rooms. The garden also stretches three-quarters of an acre. Huw Edwards, head of auctions and auctioneer at Seel  Co, said: The house itself is an attractive Victorian villa with many original features, though is currently in a poor condition with the grounds particularly to the front of the house overgrown.  In May  planning permission was granted for the demolition of the existing house and the construction of two houses and six apartments on the land instead. A cottage at the rear of the site that was converted from the villaaposs former coach house has already been flattened. The planning consent has now lapsed and came with a planning obligation under section  of the Town and Country Planning Act .  Briefly, this means that any developer must agree with the local authority, and is legally binding, to take agreed steps to reduce their impact on the local community and infrastructure. Mr Edwards added: The site is considerably larger than average for the road and could provide a development opportunity, subject to re-obtaining any necessary consents, or may be suitable for a landmark single Lisvane property considering the position and size of the plot. The existing house is in need of complete renovation but could still provide accommodation to be part of any development or demolished as per the previous planning consent. The building is going under the hammer with Seel  Co on Tuesday, December , at pm but interested parties must register via the companyaposs website in advance. title: meghan markle harry sing archies
story: Meghan Markle and Harry sing Archies favourite song at US base after court dramaMeghan Markle and Prince Harry sang Archies favourite song during a visit to McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey to meet Afghan refugees as the duchess legal case with Associated Newspapers Limited continuesThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex during a visit to Task Force Liberty at Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst Image: PAByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Nov | commentsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry sang one of their toddler Archieaposs favourite songs during a visit to a US Army base.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex spoke to recently arrived Afghan refugees at the McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey and hosted an armed forces lunch on Thursday. Former Hollywood star and mum-of-two Meghan, , led a round of heads, shoulders, knees and toes during an English lesson in which she learned Dari words. The kids were told it was one of two-year-old Archieaposs go-to songs. More than , Afghans evacuated after the country was taken by the Taliban in August as US troops were withdrawn.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  They are being temporarily housed in the base as part of Task Force Liberty where they are also being provided transportation and medical services. During the classroom visit, Meghan was snapped holding up a red pen as the kids shouted out the English words for colours. A spokesman for the Sussexes said the couple praised the tireless efforts. The visit coincided with Armistice Day as well as texts Meghan sent slamming the royals for berating Harry being made public.The duchess sent the SMS messages to ex-aide Jason Knauf in August  after Harry had stayed with Prince Charles for several days. She informed Mr Knauf she was drafting a letter to her estranged dad, Thomas Markle, at the time.  Meghan told Mr Knauf the catalyst was seeing how much pain Harry was being caused by his family in relation to her strained relationship with Mr Markle. She wrote: The catalyst for my doing this is seeing how much pain this is causing H. Even after a week with his dad and endlessly explaining the situation, his family seem to forget the context - and revert to aposcanapost she just go and see him and make this stop apos They fundamentally donapost understand so at least by writing H will be able to say to his family aposshe wrote him a letter and heaposs still doing itapos. By taking this form of action I protect my husband from this constant berating and while unlikely perhaps it will give my father a moment to pause.  Meghan sued Associated Newspapers Limited , the publisher of The Mail On Sunday and MailOnline, over five articles that reproduced parts of a personal and private letter to her -year-old dad.ANL has brought an appeal against a High Court judgeaposs decision to grant Meghan summary judgment - meaning she won her case without a trial. During the hearing this week, ANLaposs lawyers told senior judges they want to rely on new evidence from Mr Knauf - a former communications secretary to the Sussexes - who claimed that the duchess wrote the letter with the understanding that it might be leaked.After extracts of texts and emails between Meghan and Mr Knauf were used in court, further texts were made public on Friday following an application by two media outlets. Meghan previously told the Court of Appeal that the main purpose of the letter was to encourage my father to stop talking to the press after public criticism and a media onslaught surrounding Mr Markle. title: meghan markles sister samantha vows
story: Exclusive: Meghan Markles sister Samantha vows to sue over bombshell Finding Freedom claimsDuchess of Sussex Meghan Markle could face legal claim from shocked sister Samantha over name change revelations in book about the royals le, Finding Freedom and her sister Samantha" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Meghan-Markle-pictured-with-her-sister-Samantha-Markle.jpg" width"" "" Meghan Markle pictured with her sister Samantha in happier times Image: Samantha MarkleByPatrick Hill:,  Nov | commentsSamantha Markle was tonight preparing to launch lawsuits against sister Meghan in the UK and the US. She is claiming the Duchess of Sussex ly briefed about her to the authors of a controversial book. And Samantha is to meet with her legal team again on Monday about the possibility of suing Meghan for “defamation, libel and slander” as well as “breach of privacy”.She told the Sunday People : “I’m speaking to one lawyer in England and one in the US as there are dferent statutory windows and dferent issues.”Samantha, , said she was left in shock on Wednesday when Meghan apologised to the Court of Appeal after emails were disclosed, contradicting a claim that she had not collaborated with the co-authors of biography Finding Freedom.  The messages, revealed by the Duchess’ ex-communications secretary Jason Knauf, show she sent him details about Samantha and brother Thomas Jr, asking him to pass them to writers Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand. Writing in the third person, she also urged him to say that her siblings had “dropped out of high school” and that she had “never had a relationship with either of them”. She added: “Upon Meghan dating Harry, Samantha changed her name back to Markle and began a career creating stories to sell to the press. She had lost custody of all three of her children from dferent fathers.” Meghan has not spoken to Samantha since meeting Prince Harry in . Samantha, who disputes a number of Meghan’s claims, said: “I’m looking at suing for defamation in the US. In the UK, I’m looking at a breach of privacy and data privacy act breach because the statutory window for defamation is only one year in the UK.“Jason Knauf is subpoenable and the messages to [him] are evidence she was libelling and slandering me. Anything to keep this family quiet was my sister’s motto. It’s horrible.”  Wheelchair-user Samantha, who has MS, added: “I’ve never lost custody of any children. She said I changed my name when she met Harry, but I shared my name-change documents long before.” Samantha, who shares the same dad as Meghan, Thomas Snr, said they had a “normal family le” She added: “But she wanted to make us look estranged and separated to discredit us as that was an excuse to keep everybody away from the wedding.”  This week, judges heard Meghan addressed her father as “Daddy” in a letter that would “pull at the heartstrings”it ever became public. Some of her messages were presented as evidence against her claim the letter was purely private. The Mail on Sunday is seeking to overturn a High Court ruling that it unlawfully breached Meghan’s privacy by publishing extracts from it.  Meghan said she had “forgotten” giving Mr Knauf details of what to reveal to Scobie and Durand. Samantha, who has her own book, The Diary of Princess Pushy’s Sister, said: “It shows she’s manipulative.” It comes as Harry and Meghan are believed to be in talks to sign with crisis PR guru Howard Bragman, who has worked with both accusers and accused in the #MeToo movement. A source said: “Bragman is one of the most sought after PRs in the US.” Mr Bragman and the Sussexes did not respond to a request to comment. title: minecraft axolotl craze sees parents
story: Minecraft axolotl craze sees parents warned dont buy disease-carriers for ChristmasAnimal expert begs families to think carefully before getting an axolotl like the cute creatures in Minecraft because they carry disease and are actually quite boringAn axolotl in the Minecraft computer gameByPatrick Hill:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA cute amphibian is on children’s Christmas wish lists this year – but experts warn that axolotls are not the ideal pets they might seem. The photogenic creatures, stars of the video game Minecraft, grow to cm , are rampant breeders, carry disease – and don’t do much . Experts worry that once the novelty wears off, many will be abandoned. Chris Newman, of the National Centre for Reptile Welfare, cautioned: “They’re not the ideal pet for everyone. People shouldn’t buy them thinking they’re going to be like highly interactive cartoon or game console characters – they’re not. “They’re not a hugely challenging animal to look after and they’re quite cute, butI’m being perfectly honest, they’re not the most exciting either – they don’t actually do an awful lot.”  Chris, who notes that they have a lespan of approximately  years, estimates there are already tens of thousands of axolotls in captivity in the UK. And there are fears they could end up being dumped in British rivers and lakes – just as terrapins were following the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles craze of the s. And axolotls, a type of salamander native to Mexico, carry a fungal disease that has made  other species extinct.  Lana Davison, of Southwest Axolotls, said: “Some people only want them because they’re in the game. We have heard of people who have dumped axolotls in lakes.” She added: “They can breed with other things we have already in this country and become an invasive species.” The International Union for Conservation of Nature lists axolotls as critically endangered in the wild. But the amphibians are also bred in home aquariums and science labs around the world, and are widely available on the internet. They sell for anywhere between £ and £. We found one owner in Doncaster offering an axolotl for free, however, because they had “lost interest”. title: mum demands fuel refund wasted
story: Mum demands fuel refund for wasted -mile Jobcentre trip after finding note outsideAndrea Hill was furious that she had to use extra petrol money to drive to the Jobcentre after the Department for Work and Pensions failed to update her of the changes to her appointment Image: BPM MEDIAByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience WriterFahad Tariq:,  Nov | comments A single mum has asked for a refund after she drove  miles to her local Jobcentre only to discover it had been closed due to coronavirus.Andrea Hill, , slammed the Department for Work and Pensions for failing to tell her of the changes to her local Jobcentre in Stock-on-Trent, accusing them of treating her like a second-class citizen.Instead, she had travelled the  miles from her home in Biddulph at :am on the day of her appointment, only to find a sign saying that the centre was closed, reports Stoke-on-Trent Live.But the -year-old wasnapost the only one to be turned away, as the publication revealed that two bus passengers and a motorist had also turned up that morning. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. She said: It’s annoying because I paid to get there and had no idea. It was rude. If we miss our appointment or are late we get sanctioned. If you don’t turn up or you miss your appointment more than once you get sanctioned so your benefits get stopped until you go back in and explain why you were off oryou had a medical reason why you were not there. You have to inform them through your journal and it’s up to them to decidethat’s an appropriate excuse. Itaposs double standards. They’ve not notied us and there’s no sanction for them. It’s frustrating. I’m a single parent with two kids and that extra petrol money has been used. I’ve had to take time out of my day to get there. I know I am unemployed but it’s still about respect and they are treating us like we are stupid. Just because we are unemployed we are not second-rate citizens. I felt like we were treated like second-class citizens and it’s all on their terms. It’s not right.They are a double-edged sword. They can punish you for not turning up on their terms. I even asked them how do I claim my petrol back  And they said I have to do it next week when I come in. I’m not sure how much fuel it cost but it’s a -mile round trip. It cost me my time and petrol. I rushed around and got my six-year-old to school and then went straight to Kidsgrove so I could be there on time. I have got a -year-old who walks to school. I have to arrange these appointments around the school run. Andrea received a text message from the DWP regarding the cancelled appointment as she was leaving the jobcentre on Wednesday morning. The DWP has confirmed that the building was closed for a deep clean. It said staff contacted affected customers virtually. A DWP spokesman said: Staff and customer safety is our priority as our Jobcentres provide vital support to those who need it. We continue to work closely with the unions to ensure our sites are Covid-secure in line with public health and Government guidance and keep health and safety under constant review.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: mum rents childrens christmas presents
story: Mum rents her childrens Christmas presents and s them when theyre boredAfter spending seven years living in Thailand, Jen Otter moved home to the UK, with nothing more than a suitcase and no toys for her two kids, which is when she found out about WhirliJen pictured here with her daughters, Lilly and Rosie in December  Image: PA Real LeByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Nov | commentsA teacher is cutting her Christmas spending down by renting her childrenaposs presents and ing them once they are bored - which can be as early as New Year. Single mum Jen Otter, , was determined not to fill her new home with unloved toys when she ed to England in March , after living in Thailand for seven years - then five months pregnant with Rosie, now two, and with daughter Lilly, four. So, she killed three birds with one stone by joining the toy swapping website Whirli, which helps the environment by reducing waste, allows Jen to save money and cut back on clutter in her home all at the same time. Costing just £. a month- compared to a recent Nationwide building society survey claiming parents spend on average £ per child at Christmas alone - Jen of Shrewsbury, Shropshire, was thrilled by the concept. She said: Itaposs great. As a single mum, I canapost afford high-end gts, but by swapping them I can get my kids really nice presents for a fraction of the cost - and I get to send them back when theyaposre done with them! For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. The early years teacher has no qualms about ing presents the moment her children tire of them. She said: Last year I sent Lillyaposs present back on New Yearaposs Eve. She had this big Lottie treehouse with all the dolls. It was amazing and should have cost around £. But within a few days, she was bored and wasnapost playing with it anymore, so I sent it back. This has to be far better for the environment than binning unwanted items and seeing them end up in landfill. Returning from Bangkok in Thailand in  after splitting with her partner, Jen and arrived back in England virtually empty-handed.  She said: Lilly was nearly two and I was five months pregnant with Rosie. We moved in with one suitcase, so we didnapost have any toys with us. Friends offered to buy them for Lilly, but the idea of having all these new toys annoyed me because it was such a waste. She added: I witnessed her show interest in toys for a few months and then get bored of them, so I wanted to find a way to not create a lot of landfill. When her research revealed sites where she could rent toys, she decided the borrowing scheme was a far better option and meant she could afford to get them big ticket presents for Christmas and birthdays that she could never normally afford. I use it for their birthday and Christmas presents, she said. She added: My children feel treated and get access to really high-end toys which I wouldnapost be able to afford and then they go back when theyaposre done. At the moment, Rosie has this ride on recycling truck that she loves and would have cost about £ to buy. But I know in a few days sheaposll be bored of it, so itaposll be going back for another family to use. The scheme means Jen can rent toys all year round and she selects her Christmas items in early December, then s them as early as New Year. You can rent the toys for as long as you want, she said.  So there are dferent packages, but on mine I get  tokens to spend on the website, which is equivalent to £. The extra £ is for free pick up and delivery. She added: If you keep a toy for over eight months itaposs yours to keep forever andyou want a really popular toy, you can get it waitlisted. Soyouaposre organised, you could do that at the beginning of December and then hide it away until the th. Iaposve always been able to get the toys the girls want as there are so many and you never have to wait very long. She added: Last year, Lillyaposs Lottie treehouse was beautul. She woke up on Christmas morning to it and loved it.  But then, by New Year, I sent it back because she stopped playing with it. Itaposs completely normal to my daughters now for their toys not to be there forever. With a poll by the British Heart Foundation reporting that a quarter of parents admit to throwing away toys that work perfectly, while children have an average of four toys they have never played with, Jen is determined her family will buck this wasteful trend. She said: We live in a two-bedroom house and donapost have the space for lots of toys. In the past, I would buy from charity shops and then when the kids were done with the toys, Iaposd give them back. But then I worried about them not being used, as you donapost always know what will happen to that toy once youaposve given it away. She added: I like renting the kidsapos toys because instead of going to a landfill or gathering dust on a shelf, they go to another family for their children to enjoy. Obviously, my kids also have permanent toys like magnet tiles, a toy kitchen, a dolls house, wooden dolls and lots of books. But I do feel, especially with Christmas gts, that by swapping them for other toys we get the best of both worlds. And she encourages her family to buy experiences like dance lessons or theatre tickets for her girls, rather than toys, to further reduce the risk of things being thrown away. People always askthey can buy them gts, but I say no, suggesting they get them an experience instead, she said. Thataposs far more valuable and the memory will stay with them for a long time, rather than wasting money on a gt theyaposll be bored with in a matter of days. But Jen is clear thather girls love a present she will keep it. If the girls ever get really attached to something, I will buy it, she said. The site we use allows you to buy the toy youaposre renting. So a few months ago we got a Toniebox, an audio and music player, and they just loved it. She added: It stayed for about four months and in the end, I decided to buy it. The longer you rent a toy the more it decreases in value so it was actually at a discounted price when I bought it. I paid £ when it would have been £Iaposd bought it new in a shop. By doing it this way I was able to make sure that the girls liked it before spending a lot of money on it. Now Jen hopes to inspire more parents to join the Christmas revolution, by renting instead of buying their little onesapos festive gts.  I do hope people think about renting over buying, she said. She added: I think people find it hard to wrap their head around renting gts, but I think itaposs the new way to do Christmas. Sometimes I go to peopleaposs houses and there are just so many toys. They have loads of stuff and it just never gets played with. Renting toys does not reduce the fun and excitement on Christmas Day, according to Jen, who says the most expensive item she has rented was the Lottie dollaposs house. She also rented a micro scooter with a seat which would have cost approximately £ to buy. She said: I tell my daughters that I give money to Santa. Lilly will choose the toys she wants, or talk to me about them, then I hide them away for December.  She added: By swapping the kids toys throughout the year I am able to afford high end presents and not spend a fortune. I think itaposs a great idea and is a great way to ensure an exciting Christmas for the little ones without breaking the bank. It makes Christmas affordable but also it means that youaposre not buying presents for the sake of it. Youaposre getting the kids what they want. She added: Itaposs great because even though they get bored of them in a few days, we just swap them for something . Instead of the toy becoming unused, we swap it for something  they love in a few weeks time and the excitement happens all over again. Itaposs the gt that keeps on giving!Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: mum two 28 kissed boyfriend
story: Mum-of-two, , kissed boyfriend goodbye before he was killed in motorbike crashMum-of-two Amy Emanuel, , said she kissed her boyfriend Michael Maxwell, , goodbye on the morning of August , but hours later he died in a horror motorbike smash in Swansea, WalesMichael Maxwell, , was in a fatal motorbike accident in Swansea at the end of August Image: Amy EmanuelByRhodri HarrisonRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | comments A mum-of-two has shared the heartbreaking moment she kissed the love of her le for the last time before he died in a motorcycle accident aged just .Amy Emanuel kissed her partner Michael Maxwell goodbye on the morning of August , but didnapost realise it was the last time she would see him alive.Just hours later Michael tragically died in a motorbike crash in Swansea, leaving behind Amy and his two young children, Wales Online reports. Now Amy, , has shared a tribute to her beloved boyfriend and a warning for others about how quickly le can change in the blink of an eye.Plasterer Mike, who was a master of his trade, left home in Penllergaer that morning to continue developing his business to raise funds to move his family into a brand new home.Amy, who says she will never forget that day, said Mike decided to take his bike to work to enjoy the beautul weather. She told Wales Online: When I found out about an incident involving a motorbike, I immediately rang him and just knew it was him, I didn’t want to believe it and it’s hard to explain how I felt but my heart felt empty, I just knew. The pain, the heartache, feeling numb, disbelief, you don’t want to believe it and you think it will never happen to you, I still don’t want to believe it, he was so young and we just started le as a family - that’s what hurts the most. The family were expecting to move into a new home, but were unable to after Mikeaposs sudden passing. Amy said Mike was such a loving, affectionate partner, my best friend. He was a fun-loving dad to his two kids, Ayla and Zion, and his face would light up every time he would see them. Amy says itaposs heartbreaking to see the kids growing up and Mike isnapost here to see that. I am so grateful he gave us two beautul children that will live on his name forever, she said. Amy and her two children are now moving into a new home. But a tragic milestone is looming as Zion looks forward to his first birthday, but without his father. Ayla does ask to see her daddy and I have to explain heaposs not coming home which is the hardest thing I have had to do in my le, Amy said.  She said: She [Ayla] knows her daddy loves her very much and wishes he could be here and is looking down on her every day. Amy said her friends and family have given an overwhelming amount of support as have people in the community who knew Mike. I am so grateful to every single person, not just for me but our family. After Mike passed we have come together as a family and I think Ayla and Zion have played a massive part in that, they certainly keep everyone busy. Through all this heartbreak, Amy wants to raise awareness that le can suddenly change for anyone. Mike was such a positive person and that was the way to be in le, he taught me to be positive and I’m going to carry that on in his memory, times like this you have to be positive. Don’t get me wrong, I cry every day, I just miss him so much, but it’s ok to cry, it’s ok to be sad. If I’ve learnt anything it’s to be in the present rather than the future because le can change in a blink of an eye. Be grateful for every second that you get to spend with the people you love. Le is so very precious.Friends and family have been raising funds to support Mikeaposs young family during this dficult time. Among the events is a -hour marathon over Pen Y Fan mountain.To support their fundraiser you can do so by clicking here.Comment MORE ON LoveAccidentsCar crashesRoad Traffic Accidents" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-george-once-sad-over-"Bear Grylls recalls the moment Prince George ate his first antByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | commentsPrince William often speaks out on the importance of tackling climate change, solving environmental problems and promoting conservation. And it seems the threat to the natural world has also affected his eight-year-old son Prince George. Prince William once admitted the young royal was left so saddened by a Sir David Attenborough documentary about extinction, he told his father: I donapost want to watch this anymore. Speaking to Sky News last year, the future king said the episode proved too much for young George. William said: The most recent one - the extinction one - actually George and I had to turn it off, we got so sad about it halfway through. He said to me aposyou know I donapost want to watch this anymoreapos.  Why has it come to this and you know heaposs seven years old and heaposs asking me these questions already, he really feels it, and I think every seven-year-old out there can relate to that. Williamaposs comments came after George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis quizzed Sir David last year asking him questions about topics including his favourite animal, and the threat of extinction. In the cute clip, George asked Sir David which animal he thinks will become extinct next.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.The broadcaster told him: Well letaposs hope there wonapost be any because there are a lot of things we can do when animals are in danger of extinction. We can protect them.However, Sir David isnapost the only well-known person that Prince George has had the pleasure of meeting. Earlier this week, adventurer Bear Grylls recalled how he convinced George to eat an ant and has shared his excitement in convincing a future king to eat an insect. Bear was a guest at Prince William’s Kings Cup event where he struck up a conversation with the third in line with the throne. While Bear hadn’t exactly set out to convince George to eat the insect, he was stunned when the future king did agree to give it a go and said he thinks the young man is a “little hero” for throwing caution to the wind. title: prince harry contacted psychic ask
story: Exclusive: Prince Harry contacted Princess Dianas psychic to ask what happened to herPrince Harry contacted the psychic and asked What do you think about how my mother died  as well as asking about his bruv Prince William according to revelations in new bookHarry meets psychic Sally at the fancy dress do at Kensington Roof GardensByHalina WattsSunday Showbiz Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsPrince Harry contacted a ­psychic used by his late mother to ask for a reading in a bid to deal with his grief, it is claimed. Sally Morgan, who was Princess Diana’s spiritual guide, met Harry when he was seven during a visit to Kensington Palace.And as our exclusive picture reveals, they were reunited at a swanky fancy dress party where Harry rushed up to her saying: “You knew my mother.” Sally, who started her career telling futures for free but can now charge £, a session, claims: ■ She predicted Diana’s tragic end ■ She knew that Harry would marry a brunette ■ And she foretold the couple would stay together despite going through a “tempestuous time”. Sally also claims she still receives messages from beyond the grave, where Diana watches over her sons. Diana died aged  alongside partner Dodi Fayed in a  car crash in Paris. It was around  years later that Harry called Sally to ask: “What do you think about how my mother died ”  He also asked her concerned ­questions about his “bruv” Prince William – as well as what colour hair his future we would have. Sally, , recalls how she met the adult Harry at the fancy dress do at Kensington Roof Gardens around . “He was there dressed in medical scrubs,” she said. “He wouldn’t have any ­photographs taken and he came over to me and said, ‘Sally, you’re the lady who used to see my mother’. “I said, ‘Yes I did. The last time I saw you, you were about seven’. “And he said, ‘Oh, Sally, I remember, my mother would often talk about you, she spoke to you a lot’. “I said that she did and then he askedI wanted a picture. “He was with a group of lads and they were all tipsy, and I remember he bought everyone a round of drinks. It was a fun party.”  But it wasn’t until eight years ago that Sally received a phone call from Harry asking for a reading. They spoke for  minutes in what Sally believes was his first attempt to get to grips with his mental health, which he has since publicly spoken about many times. Sally said: “I was on holiday in St Tropez and he called me and the first thing he said was, ‘What do you think about how my mother died ’.” She says she told him to speak to Diana’s elder sister, Lady Sarah McCorquodale, because “she will tell you what I told her before your mother passed away”. Sally claimed: “I had spoken to Sarah before Diana’s death and had made a prediction the Queen was going to die, that she was in a really dark place and I could see a pavement. “I said they are going to drag her out and give her CPR and she is going to have a heart attack. That is what the Princess of Wales died of, a heart attack. I said a week later the Queen Mother will die because I can see her funeral. Well the Princess of Wales had the Queen Mother’s funeral that had been arranged because they had all their funerals arranged, and Diana took that. I didn’t tell Harry that though, I just told him to speak to his aunt.”  Following Diana’s death, Sarah questioned Sally about her prediction. Sally said: “After Diana died, Sarah said, ‘Well, you said the Queen’. “But I predicted that before she did the interview with Martin Bashir, where she said, ‘I want to be known as the Queen of Hearts’.” During the call with Harry, they also discussed his fears for his brother and who his own future we would be.  “How is my bruv going to be  Is he going to be OK ” she says Harry asked. Sally said she replied: “Of course he is. He will be good and he will be king, but he is in a dferent bubble to you.” She said he replied: “That is why I am always going to worry about him”. At that point Harry was still a bachelor, had dated mainly blonde women and was on off with Cressida Bonas.  But Sally says she told him he would marry someone very dferent. She said: “One of the sweetest things he said to me was, ‘What colour hair will my future we have  Will she have blonde hair ’ I said he would marry someone with dark hair.” Sally believes that their conversation was a prelude to “him waking up to his own mental health” struggles. It wasn’t until  that Harry spoke publicly about it but he has since then championed the ­subject for others.  He admitted to years of attacks both of panic and rage, disclosing that his le was in “total chaos” for two years. In her new book, Secret Spirit, Sally praises Harry’s openness, of which Diana “would have been very proud”. She says the princess told her “as a royal, you were expected to brush those kinds of feelings under the carpet”. “Harry and Meghan are helping drive the debate forward,” Sally added. Despite her le being very dferent to Harry’s, Sally can relate to his “awful” grief – she lost husband John in September, aged . They were married for  years and together for . Now, Sally is helping others with bereavement with John being her guiding light in the spiritual world. And she believes no matter what lies ahead for them Harry, , and Meghan,  – who have kids Archie, two, and Lilibet, five months – will “be together forever”, adding: “Harry will never abandon his children.”For details on Sally’s services visit sallymorgan.tv. Secret Spirit is on shelves November .Comment MORE ON Prince HarryPrince WilliamPrincess DianaRoyal FamilySunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news princess-charlotte-could-given-rare-"William and Kate share unseen photo of Princess CharlotteByKatie SewellBecca FieldTim Hanlon:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsPrincess Charlotte is already a high profile figure in the Royal Family being the only daughter of a possible future king in William - and she could be given a unique title. The six-year-old is fourth in line to the throne and already used to public events where she and her brothers have been brought up to be dignied and amazingly rarely throw tantrums. Prince Charles and William have made efforts to reduce the size of the Royal Family but Charlotte will remain a key figure andher dad does become king then she will be given a title to reflect this.The reigning monarch usually hands out new titles to royals who get married but the six-year-old may get another title altogether regardless of whether she marries or not, reports The Express. As Princess Charlotte is set one day be the daughter of the king she may well be given the Princess Royal title which is used for the eldest daughter of the British sovereign.  The title was first introduced to mimic the French royal title of Madame Royale back in the s. The is Princess Royal status is not automatically given to the king or queenaposs eldest daughter and it has to be bestowed by the monarch themselves. Currently it is Princess Anne who is the Princess Royal as she is the Queen and Prince Philipaposs only daughter. Before Princess Anne, the title was held by King George VIaposs sister, Princess Mary.Royal expert and author of Prince Harry: The Inside Story, Duncan Larcombe, told TownandCountrymag: “The title of Princess Royal is traditionally bestowed on the eldest daughter of the monarch.It is a title that remains for le, so Princess Charlotte will have to wait at least until the death of the current Princess Royal.  Princess Anne didnapost get her Princess Royal title until the Queen had been on the throne for  years. Mr Larcombe added: Princess Anne had to wait until  before her mother the Queen bestowed the title of Princess Royal on her, even though the title had been vacant since . The Princess Royal title would be separate to becoming a duchess which is a status which is sometimes given by the monarch when a member of the Royal Family marries. But there is not a lot of consistency to this as female members of the Royal Family in recent years have not been given a duchess title like Princess Margaret. In the case of the Queenaposs sister, her husband Antony Armstrong-Jones was made the Earl of Snowdon rather than a Duke. But it will be in the hands of William what royal titles he decides to give out to Charlotte and her brothers George and Louis. title: princess diana movie spencer starring
story: Princess Diana movie Spencer starring Kristen Stewart tarnishes the Royal FamilyKristen Stewart as a fairytale Princess Diana in her new film Spencer is pure fantasy - but we deserve the truth in the modern day Harry and Meghan reality showKristen Stewart as Diana, Princess of Wales in Spencer Image: Press Association ImagesopinionByRachael Bletchly:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsAmerican actress Kristen Stewart is tipped to win an Oscar for playing Princess Diana in the movie Spencer. I saw it this week and she certainly gives an extraordinary portrayal of a fragile and paranoid bulimic trapped in a miserable marriage. She even looks a bit like the princess too, thanks to skilful styling and identical clothes. But this celluloid Spencer is most definitely NOT Diana. And the depiction of her nightmare Sandringham Christmas in  is an absolute travesty. Anyone expecting a Diana biopic soon learns this is “a fable from a true tragedy”. Or rather, a fairytale woven from fact and fiction to tug at the heartstrings. I don’t expect many people will leave the cinema believing that Diana really talked to her dead father’s jacket or ate the pearls from a broken necklace with her soup.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section And even the most ardent fans would struggle to believe she was saved from suicide by the ghost of Anne Boleyn. But mixing truth and fantasy in this way is damaging – because it tarnishes the real Diana’s memory and taints the monarchy too. Netflix hit The Crown does the same. Diana’s friend Jemima Khan quit as an advisor saying the new series fails to show her enough “respect or compassion”. Prince William is furious that the focus on Diana’s final months will “perpetuate the  narratives” about his mother. But Prince Harry is keeping schtum.  He has admitted watching The Crown and says while it’s only “ loosely based on fact” he is “way more comfortable with that than I am [with] seeing stories written about my family or my we”. And, of course, there’s that £million deal he’s struck with Netflix to make his own shows. This week Meghan and Harry both took another pop at the “toxic” tabloid news media. But then Meghan had to apologise to a court for “forgetting” she had asked an aide to brief the authors of that biography she and Haz didn’t co-operate with. It was interesting that she referred to herself in the third person in emails… like the star of her own royal movie. And that she wrote a letter to her father, calling him “Daddy” in order to “pull at the heartstrings” in case it leaked. As a result of this mix-up she may now be called to give evidence on oath at a trial of her newspaper privacy claim. And while the American actress could easily give us an Oscar-winning performance, the Duchess of Sussex can’t. Because Megxit has killed this royal fairytale – and now we just want the facts. news uk-news russian-bombers-buzz-britain-before-"Tu- flight in the airspace above the North SeaByWill StewartRussia CorrespondentGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsRussian bombers were escorted away from the UK by RAF planes after aposbuzzingapos Britain Footage has emerged of the planes being intercepted before they were escorted away from the north coast of Scotland. The Tu- ‘White Swans’ targeted the North Sea, the Moscow defence ministry admitted. Their -hour flights came amid some of the highest East West tensions since the end of the Cold War three decades ago. Russia admitted that British reports were correct and the strategic bombers were escorted by RAF Typhoons as they approached the UK. It came as tens of thousands of Russian soldiers are camping near the border with Ukraine amid fears an invasion is being planned within the Kremlin. It was confirmed by the RAF that British planes had intercepted two Tu- bombers before the footage emerged.  Two strategic Tu- long-range aviation rocket carriers performed a scheduled flight in the air space above the neutral waters of the Barents, Norwegian and North Seas,” said the Russian defence ministry. “The duration of the flight amounted to about  hours.” During their voyages the Russian aircraft were intercepted and escorted by the Royal Air Force, reported TASS, citing military sources.  The Tu-s, supersonic iable sweep wing heavy strategic nuclear bombers known in the West as Blackjacks, were intercepted by Typhoons from RAF Lossiemouth and Coningsby, said British military sources. An RAF source said: Typhoon fighters were scrambled against unidentied aircraft approaching the UK area. Russia said: ”All flights of aircraft of the Russian Aerospace Force are performed in strict compliance with the international rules of using air space.”  The Mirror told of the jets being intercepted yesterday which followed a similar incident in August involving Typhoons being scrambled.Planes were also then sent from RAF Lossiemouth to intercept the Russian planes. The RAF later released an update regarding the earlier incident and said Typhoons were joined by an RAF Voyager from RAF Brize Norton which were also sent to assist.  The two Tu-s were deployed yesterday by Vladimir Putin over Belarus where a migrant camp is the focus of major international concern. The West accuses Belarus dictator Alexander Lukashenko of aposweaponisingapos asylum-seekers in a aposhybrid warapos with the West. He has allowed them to come to Belarus so they can seek to pour into Poland, Lithuania and Latvia, before seeking entry to Germany and other EU countries plus Britain. title: tiny one room house size
story: Tiny one-room house the size of a garage on sale for £K - and it needs refurbishingThe small property, located in Cha, west London, boasts a bedroom, bathroom and reception room, with the tiny kitchen area including a sink and nothing The one-room property is on the market for £, Image: Google MapsByCharlie Lawrence-JonesSam TrueloveNews reporter:,  Nov | commentsA tiny home the size of a garage is on the market for £,. The small property is  meters by . meters and is described as a excellent rental investment, as well a unique property.The aposhouseapos is located on Stewartaposs Grove in Cha, west London and apparently boasts a bedroom, bathroom and reception room, according to the listing. When looking at the floorplan, the only kitchen amenities in the aposhouseapos are a sink, reports MyLondon. There is a toilet, shower and second sink in the bathroom, however. The whole area is . sq. metres, around the size of a garage. Thereaposs no garden, front or back, with the only way in or out a door straight off the pavement.  The listing also reminds prospective buyers that the property needs refurbishment. The property description reads: A unique, freehold studio located in the heart of Cha. This ideally located property has the potential to be a fantastic London home or rental investment. Stewarts Grove is situated between the Kingaposs Road and Fulham Road. Cha Green, St Lukeaposs Gardens and South Kensington are all within walking distance. The property has been painted using bright colours, although the £, price tag may put some buyers off.Outside of London, that kind of money can get you a five bed detached house in Sheffield. Or in France,you were thinking grander, for £, you could get yourself a chateaux.Comment MORE ON House prices" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news what-queen-royal-family-typically-"The Queen arrives at Sandringham for Christmas Day serviceByMirror:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsAs the festive season begins, a team of people at the Queen’s Sandringham estate will undoubtedly be revising the Royal Family’s holiday schedule and Christmas day menu. And while the monarchs may be expected to be dining on everything from caviar to foie gras on the big day, a former palace chef has revealed the Christmas meal he served up couldn’t have been more traditional.It will be the first festive holiday in years that the Queen has sat down to a Christmas dinner without Prince Phillip, who passed away on April , aged . The late Duke of Edinburgh spent four nights in King Edward VIIaposs hospita l in central London receiving treatment for a pre-existing condition from December  in , prompting concerns he would miss out on a family Christmas.However, he was discharged at .am on Christmas Eve, allowing him to head back to Sandingham to spend Christmas with Queen Elizabeth. And on Christmas Day in , The Duke of Edinburgh was away from home on a voyage around the Commonwealth. The Queen remained at Sandringham House, where she has spent every Christmas since her father’s death in . The Royal Family’s traditional Christmas celebrations at Sandringham House are back on this year, after the Queen and Prince Philip spent the day apart from their loved ones last year for a Covid-safe affair. A former palace chef has previously spilled the beans on what their festive meal might entail describing a traditional, but fairly lavish, Christmas feast.Darren McGrady, who used to work in the royal kitchens, said the family was likely to dine on a big lunch after church, which would feature “a salad with shrimp or lobster, and a roasted turkey, and all of your traditional side dishes like parsnips, carrots, Brussels sprouts, and Christmas pudding with brandy butter for dessert”. Theyaposre actually boring when it comes to festivities. They didnapost do hams or anything, just traditional turkeys. “We did three turkeys for the Queen and her family in the royal dining room, one for the childrenaposs nursery and then more for the  or so staff, so everyone had a Christmas lunch. McGrady went on to add: “The turkey is served with mashed and roast potatoes, chestnut or sage and onion stuffing, cranberry sauce and bread sauce. Vegetables include brussels sprouts, carrots and roast parsnips.”  A traditional homemade Christmas pudding is served after the main meal and is “decorated in holly, doused in brandy, and the palace steward would carry it, flaming, into the royal dining room,” says McGrady. Mr McGrady claimed the family stuck with the same meal “year after year”. However, last year Mike Tindall gave a dferent account. Speaking on his rugby podcast last year, he said the royals do much of their festive celebrating on Christmas Eve, and give their staff Christmas Day off. Christmas Day is a little more quiet because itaposs actually a cold buffet because they give everyone the day off, and their big day is Christmas Eve,” he said. While a festive tipple would usually be considered a must on the big day, it is unclear whether the monarch will be enjoying a wine, or a gin this year, following on from reports she has been advised to go teetotal. The Queen, who has recently used a walking stick for the first time on royal visits, is said to be recovering after she had tests and spent a night in hospital last month. However, the Mirror exclusively revealed earlier this month how the Queen was “totally committed” to hosting the festive holidays for all her extended family again this year.A source said: “Her Majesty is very much looking forward to hosting her family at her Norfolk home for the Christmas holiday and there is much preparation to be done in time to accommodate everyone who has been invited. “The Queen has many happy memories of being at Sandringham with the family over Christmas.It was not yet known whether Prince Harry and Meghan Markle would be making their way over from the United States for the occasion.Comment MORE ON The QueenChristmasRoyal FamilyChristmas dinner" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: widowed mum 52 left nothing
story: Widowed mum, , left with nothing after wax burner candle sets flat on firePauline Limond, , was in the kitchen of her home near Falkirk, Scotland, when an oil wax melt burner went up in flames and set her home ablazeWidowed mum Pauline Limond, , was in her kitchen when an oil wax melt burner set her home ablaze Image: Daily RecordByRyan CarrollReporterRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | comments A widowed mum-of-two has been left with nothing after a devastating fire caused by an oil burner destroyed all of her possessions.Pauline Limond, , was hanging up washing when the blaze set off her fire alarm at around pm on Wednesday, November .Pauline had lit an oil wax melt burner in her living room after ing home from her job as a cleaner, the Daily Record reports. As the fire alarm wailed, she ran into the room and found huge flames climbing up the walls where the candle had been placed.Pauline and her son Matthew, , didnapost even have shoes on when they raced outside to safety. Fire crews rushed to the home but the flat was completely gutted, and everything not burnt to a crisp is now smoke-damaged.Pauline told the Record: Itaposs been awful. My mission is to get everyone to get rid of these candle burners.  They are lethal. I was in the house when this happened. I came in from my work and lit my candles because I love the smell of them. I went from the living room into the kitchen - and I was just hanging up washing on the phone to my aunt when five or ten minutes later I heard my smoke alarm going off. I grabbed a tea towel to wave the smoke away from the fire alarm - but then I could smell something. Out the corner of my eye I saw everything was on fire at the side where my candle was. I had dried flowers at the side of my fireplace and they had already caught fire.  By the time I was in the room there was no way I could have tackled it. I live with my youngest son and he was in the house so my priority was just to get us out. It caught very fast, it was going up the walls and everything. After running down the stairs, they heard a loud bang which also alerted their downstairs neighbours. Fire crews raced to the scene of the blaze but Paulineaposs council flat was gutted by the flames.  They managed to contain the fire to the living room but all of their possessions in the property have been smoke damaged beyond repair. Video footage and pictures show the property devastated by the blaze. The fire service contained the blaze to the living room but everything  was damaged by the smoke. Pauline fears the worst because she didnapost have insurance, which she called a luxury I couldnapost afford. Despite her best attempts to salvage some items, they all stink of smoke, she says. Pauline tragically lost her husband Ron Foster four years ago when he was diagnosed with lung cancer and died six weeks later. Family friend George Haney has set up a fundraiser to help support Pauline and Matthew and try to get them back on their feet again. The GoFundMe has already smashed itaposs target of £, with over £, in donations so far. Pauline says she has been overwhelmed by the support of the community following the tragic incident. Locals have donated clothes to the mum and son, who are currently living with Paulineaposs mum. The money raised from the Go Fund Me will go towards helping the small family pay for the deposit and initially rent payment for a private let. Devastated Pauline is now urging folk to avoid buying the wax melt burners to avoid this happening again. People need to get shot of them, I donapost want anyone  to go through this, she said.To donate to the fundraiser to get Pauline and Mathew back on their feet, click here.A Scottish Fire and Rescue Service spokesperson said: “We were alerted at .pm on Wednesday, November , to reports of a fire affecting a domestic property in Dryburgh Avenue, Denny. “Operations control mobilised three fire engines to the scene and firefighters extinguished the fire. “There were no reported casualties and crews left after ensuring the area was made safe.” Comment MORE ON FireAccidentsHouse firesFire Service" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: win 1000 christmas give your
story: Win £, Christmas to give your family their best festive season ever this yearAfter another nightmare year plagued by coronavirus, we have some much-needed cheer for you with our luxury Christmas competition. Enter now for a chance to winWin all the treats you could possibly want this ChristmasBySunday People:,  Nov | commentsIt’s the most wonderful time of the year – but just  months ago Christmas was the stuff of nightmares. Millions of us were unable to get together with our loved ones ­because of the pandemic. Many stayed away from vulnerable family members, while ­others had to cancel planned festivities due to last-minute changes to Covid restrictions. So for those who were kept apart in , this year’s Yuletide will be all the more special. And to help celebrate, The People is giving away a £, luxury Christmas package to one deserving family.  It contains everything you need to make this Christmas a cracker, from festive food kits to perfect pressies.There are gts for the whole ­family, including bikes, booze and a scrumptious Christmas dinner. And we’re even throwing in a real six-foot fir tree to put all your presents under.All you need do to be in with a chance of winning our giveaway is tell us why you deserve to win Christmas. Were you isolating because of your job  Did you need to be extra-careful to protect a loved one   Or were you simply caught up in restrictions that meant you had to keep away from your family  The big day may still be six weeks away but you can get an early gt this yearyou enter The People’s Christmas giveaway.Go to mirror winchristmas and fill in your details – and don’t forget to tell us why it is you who deserve to win Christmas. - By entering this giveaway you agree to be featured in The Peopleyou are selected as the winnerTerms and conditions This giveaway is open to anyone who is a resident of the United Kingdom except employees of Reach plc. and their immediate families. Entrants must be  years or older. To enter this giveaway you will need to submit your name and email address alongside your response to why you deserve to win this prize. You are only permitted to enter once, duplicate entries and entries suspected of foul play will be disqualied.The giveaway closes at midnight on Saturday November , . Entries received after this date will not be accepted. One winner will win a ‘Christmas bundle’ worth over £,. The winner will be selected at random from all entries. Full terms can be found at Mirror winchristmas By entering this giveaway you agree to be featured in The Sunday Peopleyou are selected as the winner. title: woman 32 who thought too
story: Woman, , who thought she was too young for cancer has breasts and oies removedEmma Hughes found a lump in her right breast and it was the start of a long and traumatic journey for her - she has spoken about the moment she was diagnosed and her journey afterwardsMum-of-two Emma Hughes, , is supporting the Stand Up To Cancer campaign Image: Matthew HorwoodByMark Smith:,  Nov | comments A young woman has bravely opened up about being diagnosed with cancer and having to have her breasts and oies removed. At the age of , mum-of-two Emma Hughes thought she was too young to have cancer, Wales Online reports. But after finding a lump in her right breast she decided to go to her GP just to be cautious. It was the start of a long and traumatic journey for Emma who not only needed both breasts removed, but also both oies which brought on early menopause. Emma is sharing her story to support the Stand Up To Cancer campaign in Wales. I ignored it for a while, but eventually went to my GP when it didnapost go away and seemed asit might be getting bigger, recalled Emma, who first saw her doctor in . The GP assured me it was probably nothing because of my age, but did refer me to the breast clinic where after being examined I was given an ultrasound. When they did another in my armpit area and said they wanted to take biopsies I began to worry, although at  I still did not think it could be cancer.  Emma said she was taken into a room and askedshe could come back the following Friday to discuss her results. I brought my sister with me when I came back to be given the devastating news that I had breast cancer which had spread to my lymph nodes, she said. It was a complete and utter shock and my sister was in tears. I felt guilty for putting her through this, at the same time thinking I was going to die and worrying about my sons.I had such an intense feeling of guilt that I had waited before going to the doctor to get the lump sorted, and I was scared.I then had a lot of scans and blood tests to see what kind of cancer it was. It was a relief to find it was still at stage three and not spread anywhere .Sharing the news with her two sons Iestyn, , and Bailey, , was dficult for Emma, now .My younger son has autism and profound learning dficulties - he is non-verbal. But my eldest, who was  at the time, is quite grown up and took it very well when I told him, with the support of the family care nurse, that I had cancer. We gave him a child-friendly book to explain everything, and I made it clear to him I was never going to give up fighting it.The boysapos father helped take care of the kids, even though we are not still together, and social workers helped me get respite care. I also had my sister, mum, dad and friends around me who were all fantastic. Emma had six rounds of chemotherapy and  sessions of radiotherapy. As a preventative measure, she also had her breasts and oies removed.She said: I lost all my hair, including my brows and lashes, and felt exhausted and sick. My treatment was finished by the end of June, , and my oncologist called me in to discuss preventative treatment. My cancer was hormone-based so he suggested removing my oies.In October I had the operation, and in February, , I had a double mastectomy with reconstruction as a further preventative measure. It was a good thing I did, as pathology after the operation showed traces of cancer the size of a grain of sand, although they had not shown up on a CT scan prior to surgery.I am now on Letrozole which makes me a bit tired and achy and I will have to stay on for  years.Emma, from Blackwood, described how her cancer diagnosis led to positive changes in her le. She said: Since the end of my cancer treatment I have gone from strength to strength, in spite of the oy removal putting me into early menopause which gave me hot flushes and panic attacks which I realise, having had counselling before my operation, are just hormonal.I have lost three stone, left my job at a call centre and am training as a nurse. I have turned my le around and have a new outlook. I no longer take anything for granted and try to appreciate all the little things. I realise health is wealth you can have everything, butyour le is on the line, nothing  matters.Emma is backing the Stand Up To Cancer campaign in Wales, the joint fundraising effort from Cancer Research UK and Channel , and is calling on everyone to stand united against the disease by raising money to accelerate le-saving research.Itaposs thanks to research and treatment that I’m still standing and can look forward to a future full of special moments with my loved ones, she added.In Wales, around , people are diagnosed with cancer every year. Stand Up To Cancer helps to take breakthroughs from the lab and transform them into cutting-edge treatments that could help save the lives of more people like Emma. To donate or fundraise, visit suc.org.uk Emma added: With charities having been hit so hard by the pandemic, it feels more important than ever for everyone to do what they can. So, I hope people in Wales will stand up for me and everyone affected by this devastating disease. The campaign, now in its ninth year in the UK, has raised more than £m, funding  clinical trials and projects involving over , cancer patients across the country. These include the development of new treatments that use viruses to fight cancer, clinical trials testing potentially more effective ways to deliver radiotherapy and improved surgical techniques for bowel cancer. Ruth Amies, Cancer Research UK spokeswoman for Wales, said: We are very grateful to Emma for helping us to continue our mission. One in two of us will get cancer in our letime, but all of us can play a part to help beat it. By raising vital funds, supporters could make a real dference to people like Lizzy. Every penny will go directly to our le-saving research, helping our tireless scientists to develop tests and treatments for those who need them most. If we all stand together, we can save lives. title: woman pulled aside boss told
story: Woman pulled aside by boss and told she cant use office microwave for breakfastThe woman, who says her job "requires a lot of concentration, "says her line manager recently pulled her to one side to let her know her behaviour "had been noticed"" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Woman-using-a-microwave.jpg" width"" "" The woman shared the scenario on MumsnetImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByKate LallyDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Nov  A woman claims she was pulled aside at work and told by her boss she is not allowed to use the staff microwave to warm her breakfast up.The woman, who works full time and says her job requires a lot of concentration and is computer-facing all day says her line manager recently pulled her to one side to let her know her behaviour had been noticed.She says she was told that the microwave and toaster were only for lunch breaks, unless she decided to split her break over both, the Liverpool Echo reports. Posting on Mumsnet, the woman wrote: I canapost eat first thing in the morning so I have always eaten mid-morning, at my desk, sometimes something cold, sometimes something that needs a minute or two in the staff microwave.Past employers have never had an issue with this. Iaposm fairly new to this job but in the past two months, no-one has ever raised it as an issue. We have access to a microwave and toaster so sometimes Iaposll bring in a tub of beans, or eggs that Iaposve already put in a bowl and whisked at home so it takes  minutes in the microwave to heat them.  All during the space of time it takes me to make my first cup of tea of the day - which is taken after having already put in - hours work since I got in that morning. All of a sudden my line manager took me aside and said aposit had been noticedapos that I was heating up my breakfast and that I was no longer to do this as it was in work time, that the microwave and toaster were only for lunch breaks, unless I decided to split my break over both. The woman continued: This seems ridiculous to me as it takes max  minutes and I then bring it back to eat at my desk whilst working. I have seen colleagues gone for much much longer than thisthey get into social conversation with colleagues. Also, this instruction was directed only to me, not the team or department as a whole, so it feels very personal. The woman said is important to take regular breaks throughout the day. She added: Am I being unreasonable here  Do others do this at work with no issue  As I said, past employers have never had issue with it and I donapost take the p*** with it. One mum said the woman wasnapost being treated like an adult. She continued: It annoys me when a workplace doesnapost treat people like adults. So I would probably sweetly say aposOkay thataposs fine, Iaposll take the five minutes out of my lunch hour and just have a  minute lunch breakapos. I imagine smokers take up much longer out of their day to have smoke breaks. Others thought the woman was in the wrong. One mum wrote: Beans egg on toast is taking the p*** and stinks the office out. Iaposve never, ever seen anyone at work have more than a bowl of cereal or a yogurt. You are being unreasonable - and cheeky. Another said: I used to have a colleague who did this and it annoyed me so much. While she was stirring up her porridge and blowing it to cool it down, she couldnapost properly perform tasks. She could only type with one hand, often couldnapost answer the phone as she was chewing. It would take her longer to so a simple email or input some data while she was eating than it would normally, and while this was only for - minutes per day, it was every day and very annoying. Also microwave eggs stink.
