story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. title: aberdeens dean sutherland wins wbc international silver title with stoppage victory
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. title: aberdeen grammar mark new
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 5 2021
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowCaring for the carersThroughout the hardships and challenges of the pandemic, carers have become valued members of families who could barely have survived without them.Providing care for a person in their own home can be le-changing, offering them safety, independence and companionship.There can be few more vital roles to be played in society but are these invaluable people not themselves being supported Caring for the carers by investing in their teams, their working conditions and their pay must be the first priority of the mooted National Care Service, and in the meantime urgent action is needed to attract and retain staff in these crucial roles.When somebody chooses to train for this dficult, but hugely rewarding, career they should feel safe in the knowledge that they will be supported, paid a good wage and not be forced by shortages to offer anything other than the high quality, professional service they so badly want to deliver.RemembranceFor a hundred years communities across the UK have come together to honour all who have lost their lives in wars and military campaigns.These precious acts of remembrance were curtailed last year due to Covid restrictions, so perhaps this year it is more important than ever to head out to churches and cenotaphs all around our community, and together we will remember them.

title: your pictures november 12 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt#s a special photograph this week for our weekly Your Pictures feature.The fantastic image was sent to us by regular contributor Aileen Gillies, now a photographer with a growing reputation and wide range of calendars to her credit.Aileen sent us this photograph of the sunset at Arduaine, taken on Tuesday November . She also mentioned that this was her #birthday sunset#.So, it might be a few days late, but happy birthday Aileen!

title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: tayvallich group joins musical call for action
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowColin CameronA tidal wave of music crashed on to the shores of the River Clyde and COP earlier this week # an anthem for action on climate change.Among hundreds of music makers from around the globe making their presence felt was a group of people from Mid Argyll.The idea was born early in . As COP was originally to be held in November that year, a small group of Scottish artists planned to use the power of music in a live performance to promote global wellbeing and climate justice.With pilot funding from Creative Scotland, community music group Oi Musica, specialising in street band music, joined forces with the all-inclusive Soundhouse Choir and award-winning folk musician Karine Polwart.As inspiration, Karine drew on the mythology of Saint Mungo and Glasgow#s famous #the tree, the bird, the fish and the bell#.The song Enough is Enough was born.As the pandemic took hold and the conference was postponed, plans changed. The piece became a music video, and the idea to invite many more people to add their voice took shape.An invitation was put out to community groups to record their own version of the song to increase pressure on leaders to make decisive action at COP .Described as #a crashing, tumbling outpouring of music that starts with a few small drops, gathering pace and momentum as more people join, and building to a climax# the full force was unleashed at .pm on Wednesday November  in Govan with a mass performance as part of COP .At Govan was Tayvallich-based musician Sarah Phizacklea # but on the Saturday before travelling to Glasgow Sarah invited a group of people from Tayvallich, Carsaig and Crinan to her barn to create their version of Enough is Enough.Sarah explained: #It felt wonderful to add some weight to such an important cause, a bit more pressure on our leaders to actually commit to tackling climate change. And it was so much fun!#Our video has been uploaded to the growing collection of voices from all over the country and globally.#There were about  of us in total. It was filmed by Mark and Jane Smith, James Lehmann did the sound recording and the singers were Mary McNeill, Iona Barr, Kathie Baer, Kathie Fe, Jan Aksnes, Charlie Silverton, Ulla Hammervig, Fiona Lowrie, Biddy Simpson, Mary McLauchlan and Val Beattie.The band were Nils Aksnes, Keira Anderson, Kevin Williams and Hugh Fe. Nicholas Mes of the Tavallich shop fed us a fabulous warming stew.#She added: #I know the people who wrote it and thought the idea of everyone singing the same song with the same message was so powerful and gave a feeling of hope, that together we can solve the climate crisis.#The group#s video can be seen on Facebook or on Vimeo vimeo #. Check out letitgrow.scot for more information on the wider project.Search #MusicforCOP to find all the videos.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 12 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowNo matter how frustrating the Covid clerical fiasco has been, there is no excuse for taking it out on vaccination staff at clinics.They have worked beyond the call of duty during the pandemic and continue to be there to help us.Questions, however, must be asked over the management of the Covid booster programme.Senior NHS Highland and HSCP managers must bear responsibility for the needless mistakes, many of which a little local knowledge could have quickly rectied.We detected, in the response to our enquiries, a note of irritation at NHS staff time taken up addressing media questions as the confusion unfolded.The situation is entirely of NHS senior management#s making, and the media has every right to ask questions of a publicly-funded service on behalf of the people of Argyll and Bute.We hope and trust, however, that the admin problems have now been resolved.That aside, thank you to all the NHS staff helping each of us by delivering vital Covid booster jabs # it is genuinely appreciated while the virus remains a threat.And this Sunday at am, let#s think about others who made unimaginable sacrices on our behalf.Lest we forget.

title: half-price-tickets-now-available-see-tapestry
story: THE GREAT Tapestry of Scotland has been awarded Visit Scotlandrsquos Days Out Incentive Fund.The Tapestry tells the inspirational true story of the countryrsquos history, heritage and culture . It was hand stitched by over  people in communities across Scotland and transported by land, sea and air to come together.It is made up of   and  miles of wool .The visitor centre in Galashiels will now be offering half price day tickets from Monday  November  until  February .During this special offer adult tickets will be pound., concession tickets pound., child ticket pound., Burns family ticket  tickets at pound per ticket, Inglis family ticket  tickets at pound. per ticket.Half-price tickets can be purchased online at: www.greattapestryofscotland or in the centre from Monday  November.

title: borders-activists-mark-cop26-weekend-events
story: ALTHOUGH a great number of activists flocked to COP in Glasgow this weekend, environmentalists in the Borders also shone a spotlight on climate issues here.Supporters of the Fridays For Future campaign joined the weekly silent vigil in Melrose in solidarity with the Fridays For Future march which took place in Glasgow, led by Greta Thunberg.As well as the silent vigil, climate activists in the Borders also took part in a series of events over the weekend, including the Great Borders River Clean and the Borders Book Festival.ldquoTheyrsquore all lsquoclimate beaconsrsquo showing we care for the future of the planet, said Greener Melrose chairman Donald McPhillimy of the weekendrsquos events.ldquoWe feel itrsquos good to celebrate this, while COP is happening, so wersquove launched an appeal for groups, organisations, businesses, organic producers etc in the Borders to send us details about their green activities, and how others can get involved.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedOn Saturday, Greener Melrose met with cyclists who had been loaned Ebikes as part of Ebikes for Borderers ndash a scheme to help people seethey would be a suitable replacement to their car for work or leisure purposes.And over the course of the weekend volunteers across the region joined the Great Borders River Clean, helping to collect rubbish and debris from river banks.Volunteers from Greener Melrose were also at the Borders Book Festival recently with a display of their activities and promoting their map of eco-friendly actions being taken around the Borders. This tied in with talks at the festival from Tom Heap who discussed his new book  Ways to Save the Planet and a presentation from journalist Robert Peston about his experiences at COP.A lsquoGreen Beacons of Hopersquo list is being produced in the Borders to highlight what actions are being taken locally to help tackle the climate crisis, to highlight the green activities people can join in with..removeMr McPhillimy said: ldquoJoining with others, to do something positive, is a great start to helping communities be resilient to the effects of climate change, and it feels good to be working with nature, helping restore decades of damage. It certainly beats feeling anxious and helpless in the midst of all the dire warnings wersquore no longer able to ignore. The first step can be to check out whatrsquos already happening.:Services to be affected by lsquoRemembrance Day closurersquo, says Borders BusesGreen activities being included range from growing your own fruits and vegetables to upcycling old clothes and household items.For more information about Greener Melrose activities, the green map and Beacons of Hope listing, contact greenermelrose@live

title: updated-book-commemoration-remembers-gala-woman
story: THE ONLY woman from Galashiels who died during active service in World War II was remembered recently with the publication of the revised edition of the townrsquos Book of Commemoration.Fay T. Currie, an aircraftwomen nd class, WAAF, was only  years old when she lost her le on the th September , following an illness while serving her country. She passed away at Bridge of Larne and is interred at Galashiels Eastlands Cemetery.Gordon Keddie, a volunteer researcher said: ldquoOur group felt it was important those who lost their lives in WWII should be remembered in the same way as was done with those from WWI in , when the book was published.The Book of Commemoration, which lists the iniduals from the town who gave their lives in both World Wars, was produced by Energise Galashiels Trust and has been updated recently following a yearlong project when a group of volunteers researched each of the  men and one woman fallen from World War II, including poignant photos of the townsfolk.The Book of Commemoration is a legacy to Gala Remembers, the extensive programme of activities that took place in  to commemorate the th anniversary of the end of World War I.Debbie Paterson, EGT committee member, added: ldquoWhile the work of Energise Galashiels Trust is often future-focused, it is important that we reflect back in time too, especially when remembering the people of the town who made the ultimate sacrice by giving their lives to ensure we today enjoy our freedoms. We are honoured to be able to continue to support the Book of Commemoration this year with the addition of more detail and images of the WWII fallen.Energise Galashiels Trust would like to thank Jenner McLaughlin, Hazel Hunter, Tommy Turnbull, and Gordon Keddie for their tireless work that resulted in the comprehensive revision of the Book.

title: coronavirus-borders-recorded-tan-70-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash two fewer than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: galashiels-20mph-speed-limit-set-reversed-roads
story: THE mph speed limit on some Galashiels roads will be removed, a councillor has revealed.Scottish Borders Council introduced the controversial restrictions in October  as part of a trial under its Spaces for People scheme.At a meeting of the community council on Wednesday , Galashiels representative Harry Scott announced that some ldquorevisions are set to go ahead.ldquoTherersquos been some criticism and some love of them [the limits] but the plan at the moment is for a revision, the independent councillor said.:Gala remembers only woman from town to die on active service in WWAccording to Mr Scott, the mph limit will be reinstated ldquoon the road leading to the recycling centre past Melrose Gait and Coopersknowe.A ldquobuffer zone of mph will also be placed from the town boundary on Melrose Road to near the junction with Hawthorn Road, with new mph signage to be erected from that point to indicate the change in limit.Winston Road will also have its mph limit reinstated down to the roundabout with Galafoot, says Mr Scott.He confirmed that the mph limit will stay on Wood Street, as well as on ldquoall the residential schemes in the town.Member of the public Richard Lees said that ldquoa lot of people have universal disapproval of these mph limits on social media, and asked Mr Scottthe council has a way of measuring the advantages of the scheme.:Borders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsResponding, Mr Scott said: ldquoIrsquom not an expert but I do knowa child is struck at mph they have got a  per cent more chance of surviving thantheyrsquore struck at mph.ldquoThere have been some concerns about an increase in pollution but Irsquom reliably told that a car travelling at mph in the proper gear exerts less pollution than one travelling at mph.ldquoMy information is that the mph limit is overall a good thing. I do share with you some reservations about whether mph is really a requirement for a lsquothrough roadrsquo in a town but I think what is being proposed by the officer is reasonable and I certainly donrsquot have any objection to it..removeThe mph speed restrictions are part of an -month council trial covering  towns and villages in the Borders.The aim of the scheme is to make it easier for people to safely walk and cycle during everyday journeys.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedChanges to the restrictions were also announced at a meeting of Selkirk Community Council meeting on Monday .On the A into Selkirk from Galashiels the mph is to be reinstated up to Viewfield Park, then mph through the town thereafter.A mph limit on the A from Hawick will also be reinstated ndash however police and road safety officers have yet to decide where.

title: westruther-woman-admits-drink-driving-offence-weekend
story: A BORDERS woman appeared from custody at Jedburgh Sherf Court on Monday and admitted a drink-driving offence at the weekend while already disqualied.Fty-one-year-old Joyce Barrett, of Westruther, also pleaded guilty to having no insurance.Sentence was deferred until next month for the production of background reports and she was released on bail.You might also be interested in:mph speed limit set to be reversed on Galashiels roads, meeting hearsBorders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsDog fouling in the Borders is getting worse and worse, says Gala councillor

title: 3-000-half-price-tickets-available-abbotsford-house
story: VISITORS can explore Sir Walter Scotts beautul Scottish Borders home at Abbotsford for half price thanks to a limited offer as part of the Visit Scotlands Great Days Out in Scotland scheme.There are nearly , half-price tickets to claim, and the offer includes entry to the House, Chapel and Gardens.It also includes half price entry to Christmas  in the historic house, which opens on December th.This magical Christmas experience will allow visitors to explore the house as it might have been for Christmas in Scotts day including a special edition Christmas audio guide.Giles Ingram, Abbotsfordrsquos Chief Executive said: ldquoLast year we extended the season for the first time in seven years, and wersquove decided to do the same again in Scottrsquos th anniversary year, making the event even bigger and better!ldquoWersquore delighted that for the first time ever Father Christmas will be on site to meet local children and our Christmas Market will now be over two weekends in November. The historic house will be open for longer, decorated for the celebrations and telling the story of a special festive season for Scott, when he celebrated the completion of his wonderful home.ldquoAlthough  hasnrsquot been as dficult as , we have missed our international and group visits, which were an important part of our income. Thankfully we have continued to welcome visitors from across the UK and our local market has been very supportive, especially helping us to celebrate Scottrsquos th birthday at Scottfest  in August. Wersquore now inviting them to come again and celebrate a very special Christmas with us.The celebrations at Abbotsford begin with a Christmas Market over the last two weekends in November, featuring local crafters and suppliers. The Markets will run from .am ndash pmon Saturday and Sunday, th  st and th  th November. Christmas wreath making workshops are running on Friday th November..removeThe historic house will close as usual on Tuesday November th and then re-open on Saturday th December, beautully decorated with foliage from the estate and with a unique literary inspired Christmas tree in Scottrsquos magnicent Library.Also on Saturday th December, Father Christmas will arrive at Abbotsford for the first time. Local children can meet him and his Elves in his festive grotto every Friday, Saturday and Sunday until th December.A Christmas shopping evening will be held in the Abbotsford gt shop on Thursday nd December where visitors can find unique presents, including a range of exclusive items created to celebrate the th anniversary of Sir Walter Scott, including Abbotsford gin  whisky.Ochiltreersquos cafeacute will also remain open throughout December for visitors to enjoy their Christmas menu and festive treats. The gt shop and cafeacute are open seven days a week, am-pm, until rd December and am-pm on Christmas Eve. They are also open thndash th Dec, am-pm, and st Dec, am-pm.Visitors should check the opening dates and times before visiting.Full details of dates, times and tickets for events are on Abbotsfordrsquos web site: scottsabbotsford

title: coronavirus-scottish-government-shares-borders-case-update
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash one fewer than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: bright-side-life-hailed-huge-success
story: THE BRIGHT Side of Le benefit show which lit up the Eastgate Theatre last month has been hailed a huge success and could potentially become an annual event.Local community drama group Tweed Theatre brought together, over two nights on nd and rd October, a slew of talented local performers to celebrate the resurgence of performing arts.Tweed Theatre itself, along with the Downright Homespun Radio Company, Sara Bolesrsquo Stride Young Dancers and Eastgate Follies, Shakespeare at Traquair and Celtic Beat with Joe Wilton, collaborated in a production lasting a little over an hour which showcased the cream of local talent in a fabulously upbeat celebration of live drama, comedy, music and dance.The eveningrsquos entertainment involved hysterically funny satirical sketches from DHRC, superb dancing from Sara Bolesrsquo young and mature artists, a scintillating  minute Hamlet from Shakespeare at Traquair, two classic excerpts from Tweed Theatre-one from an Alan Bennett monologue and the other Mrs Culfeatherrsquos mince from The Steamie, and all rounded off by Nomad Beatrsquos sensational Celtic Beat grouprsquos foot-tapping music.The finale saw the audience joyfully joining in two verses of the immortal Monty Pythonrsquos Always Look on the Bright Side of Le, the song after which the show was named.The production was so successful, raising a considerable amount for the Eastgate Theatre, sending people home happy on both nights and encouraging local performers to collaborate creatively, that there is a feeling amongst the performers that the iety benefit show could become a regular event. Watch this space!Organisers wish to thank the ferociously talented artists who came together and say that it was worth the six months of planning to see the audience spilling into the street entertained and looking forward to what we all hope will be a completeto enjoying the thrill of live performance.

title: club-international-rugby-fans-oval-ball
story: Itrsquos a diluted card of club rugby for supporters in the Borders this weekend but a few exciting games are still taking place.Tonightthere will be a Borders derby in the Premiership when Jed-Forest host Selkirk.In National League Division One Melrose have an away fixture against the Stirling Wolves.In East League Division One Duns have a home game against Haddington and Hawick Force play Hawick Linden in a friendly at Mansfield Park.Tomorrow Gregor Townsend on-form Scotland side face world champions South Africa at BT Murrayfield.In the National League Division one Biggar travel to face Ayr and in National League Division Three Berwick are away to Strathmore.In East League Three Gala YM host Lasswade.In Reserve League East One Biggar A host Jed-forest A whilst on Reserve League East Two Gala A host Lasswade and Kelso Sharks take on Watsonians at Poynder Park.In the Semi-Junior Borders League Jed Thistle face Hawick Youth, Kelso Harlequins meet Gala Wanderers, Melrose Wasps host Duns Colts, Peebles Colts are at home to Carlisle Colts and Selkirk Youth host Morpeth Colts.On Sunday Kelso Ladies host Broughton.In Edinburgh Scotland Women face Japan at the Dam Health Stadium.Kick off times y so always check before going along to the games.

title: a7-driver-overturned-lorry-taken-bgh-serious-injury
story: THE driver of an overturned lorry has been taken to Borders General Hospital with a ldquoserious injury, say police.Officers say they were called to reports of the vehicle on the A near Crude Hill in the early hours of Friday morning .The driver, in his twenties, was taken to hospital.:mph speed limit set to be reversed on Galashiels roads, meeting hearsThe road has been closed to recover the vehicle, according to police.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoPolice were called to the A near Crude Hill around .am on Friday,  November, following a report of an overturned artic lorry.ldquoThe driver, in his twenties, was taken to Borders General Hospital with a serious injury.ldquoThe road has been closed to facilitate recovery of the vehicle and officers continue to liaise with the relevant partner agencies.

title: jim-telfers-contribution-world-rugby-recognised
story: BORDERS rugby legend Jim Telfer is to be inducted into World Rugbyrsquos Hall of Fame .The former Hawick High School and Gala Academy headmaster won  caps for Scotland,  as captain.And he made eight test appearances for the British and Irish Lions, on two tours, in  and .A tenacious back-row forward for Melrose, Telfer has the distinction of being the only Scotland international to have played New Zealand, South Africa and Australia without losing.Following his playing career, he became one of the most revered coaches in the game.He coached the Lions on their  tour to New Zealand, Scotland to the Five Nations Grand Slam in  and, as assistant to Sir Ian McGeechan, to a second Grand Slam in .After a break from coaching, Telfer was invited by McGeechan to become forwards coach on the triumphant Lions tour of South Africa in .Through his technical know-how and stirring motivational speeches, Telfer galvanised a Lions pack written off by the press and they laid the  for a - series victory.Telfer, with the assistance of John Rutherford and Hugh Campbell, was successful again in  as Scotland claimed the last-ever Five Nations title under their management.The six stars were selected by the Hall of Fame committee. This comprises of John Eales, David Hands, Henri Garcia, Pablo Mamone, Rob Cole, Anna Richards and Wayne Smith.Eales, the chair of the committee, said: ldquoThe  inductees for the World Rugby Hall of Fame are representative of all that is good in our game. Each of them have been outstanding players in either sevens or s and they have also been important contributors to rugby, in their own countries and globally, off the field.

title: gala-fairydean-rovers-announce-new-initiative-youngsters
story: Gala Fairydean Rovers Academy players will now be invited to all home first team matches with free entry.The Lowland League Club feel that it is important for the youngsters to see where the GFR pathway leads to.Neil Hastings has also voiced his support and looks forward to seeing all players and coaches down at Netherdale soon.He said: ldquoWhen I first arrived at the club it was clear to see there was  still is a lot of excellent work going on with the youth academy. As someone who has always had an interest in youth development and also someone who has worked at ious clubs with youth players, I understand all the dficulties and challenges along the way.ldquoFirst and foremost, when I arrived at the club I had to concentrate on the st team and this will obviously always be my number one focus. However, I now believe we are moving in the right direction, and I really want to try and create a real family environment at the club.ldquoNothing would make me happier on a Saturday to walk out at pm and see as many of the young GFR family shouting, cheering, and supporting the st team. We have the full pathway now for young players at the club from starting their football journey Up to under s football and then the lowland league side.ldquoI think its important for a young players development that they see where they are aiming to try and play. I have spoken with Davie about a few ideas to try and build a relationship between the First team and the young players as I understand its a two-way street and we cant just ask for them to come along a create an atmosphere. I would love for us to get to a point in a few yearrsquos time where we dont need to ask for ball boys, mascots or for them to attend but to hear that theyre heading to Netherdale for the game with their friends anyway.

title: shona-haslam-scottish-borders-council-leader-step
story: SHONA HASLAM is stepping down as leader of Scottish Borders Council, it has been announced.The Conservative councillor for Tweeddale East was appointed as head of the council in .But she is now set to step away from the role to lead a new think tank ldquothat focuses on how we build a stronger community in Scotland for the future.She will remain an elected member for Tweeddale East until the local government election in May next year.Elected members will choose a new leader at the full council meeting on November .Mrs Haslam said: "It has been an honour and a privilege to serve as council leader over the last four years. We have achieved so much including the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal, the launch of South of Scotland Enterprise, destination play parks, and iPads to all of our learners through the award winning Inspire Learning programme.ldquoIt has not been an easy four years either with serious floods in our towns, a fire at Peebles High School and of course COVID-. Our communities have joined forces and pulled together in all of these challenges and to see how this has happened has been one of the best things about this role.ldquoI am not leaving the public sector, or politics, and will be leading a new think tank in Scotland that focuses on how we build a stronger community in Scotland for the future.ldquoI am excited about the future and the opportunities it holds and know that the Scottish Borders is going to continue to grow from strength to strength.Council convener David Parker said: "I would like to thank Shona for her work as leader over the past four years and congratulate her on all she has achieved. She has made an enormous contribution to the Scottish Borders.ldquoThe focus she has placed on mental health and the huge amount of work she carried out on Inspire Learning in our schools are just two of the things I think she deserves great credit for.ldquoAs the first female leader of this council she will have a special place in its history..removeldquoI look forward to welcoming and working with the new leader after the council meeting later this month."

title: a7-closure-borders-buses-suspends-x95-services-rest-day
story: BORDERS Buses has suspended X services between Hawick and Carlisle due to a closure on the A.Police were called to reports of an overturned lorryat around .am today , with officers closing the road to recover the vehicle.And Borders Buses says it has taken the ldquohard decision to stop all remaining X services for the remainder of the day due to the closure.A spokesperson for the travel company said: ldquoWe have been informed that the A closure is expected to remain in place for most of the day.ldquoAs this closure is out with our control, we have taken the hard decision to suspend all remaining X services between Hawick and Carlisle for the remainder of today.:Shona Haslam to step down as leader of Scottish Borders CouncilIt is the companyrsquos intention toto normal tomorrow, but this is ldquoonly an optionthe road reopens.According to Traffic Scotland, the A is now running under temporary traffic lights at Canonbie following the overnight incident.Meanwhile, police have confirmed that a crash took place in Stow last night.There were no injuries, according to officers.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoWe received a report of a road traffic crash involving a car and a lorry on the A Galashiels Road in Stow around .pm on Thursday, November , .ldquoThere were no injuries reported and vehicle recovery was arranged.

title: borders-recorded-70-coronavirus-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus.An issue with the linkage of testing data to hospital activity data forced NHS Borders to revise its hospital occupancy figures reported between October  and  November, .This issue resulted in the number of patients being undercounted.From October -November  there were between  and  people in hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of coronavirus.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: selkirk-invited-take-part-canadian-christmas-festival
story: SOUTERS are once again invited to take part in an international Christmas event with other towns and cities named Selkirk.Last year the town was invited to join the Holiday Alley festival held in the city of Selkirk in Manitoba, Canada, which was forced online due to the coronavirus pandemic.As part of the festival in , Selkirk communities around the world were invited to film themselves singing and dancing to a version of the  Days of Christmas. However, this year those wanting to get involved will be singing and dancing along to Dance in the Street, Again ndash written by Selkirk, Manitoba, artist Brenton Thorvaldson and based on the original song Dancing In The Street by Martha and the Vandellas.Organisers of Holiday Alley have also prepared choreography for Souters to follow or you can create your own moves.All the submitted videos will then be edited together in the lsquoWorldwide Dancing in the Street Videorsquo that will air on Holiday Alley web-TV on Tuesday, November . Anyone wishing to take part in this yearrsquos video, should submit their contributions to the Holiday Alley team by November . Visit: forms.gle NDfzbEshVpsEMJ

title: borders-volunteers-join-great-borders-river-clean
story: VOLUNTEERS across the Borders grabbed their bin bags last weekend to help support the Great Borders River Clean.Almost  communities in the region took part in the clean-up which aims to remove waste a debris from local rivers between Friday and Sunday. Over the weekend more than  volunteers gathered, collecting around ,kg of rubbish.Tom Rawson, founder of Green Tweed Eco and the Great Borders River Clean, said: ldquoThis was the fourth edition of a series of region-wide events that have seen over ,kg of rubbish removed from the Tweed, Teviot and major tributaries.ldquoWith the support of Tweed Forum and the Fallago Environment Foundation, the Great Borders River Clean has grown into one of the UKrsquos largest river clean events.Volunteers joined river clean groups in Ancrum, Peebles, Melrose, Darnick, Chirnside, Tweedbank, Galashiels, Coldstream, Innerleithen, Traquair, Hawick, Selkirk, Walkerburn, Earlston, and Kelso.Mr Rawson, who is a teacher at St Maryrsquos Primary School in Melrose, added: ldquoPerhaps most exciting, this edition saw the involvement of school groups with pupils from Earlston High, Ancrum and Newtown St. Boswells primary schools working really hard to rid their local streams of rubbish.ldquoNewtown St. Boswells Primary School even made a superb film of their efforts.ldquoThis is something that I would like to encourage in future and I am currently seeking to raise funds for the introduction of a Borders-wide prize to encourage participation and the engagement of young people in the fight against rubbish and littering.ldquoAt a time when the world was focused on events at COP in Glasgow, it was lovely to see the towns and villages of the Borders working together to improve the natural environment at a local level.

title: photo-charles-beaming-bench-marks-73rd-birthday
story: The Prince of Walesrsquo rd birthday has been marked with a new photograph showing him sitting on a bench at Highgrove.The future king is pictured smiling at the camera against the backdrop of verdant gardens at his home in Gloucestershire.He is wearing a blue pinstripe suit, light blue tie and dotted pocket square.A purple flower adorns his lapel.vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Walesrsquo rd birthday has been marked with a new photograph showing him sitting on a bench at Highgrove The photo was taken in the summer, according to Clarence House.The photographer was Hugo Burnand, who took wedding pictures for Charles and Camilla in  and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in .Charles also asked the photographer to take the birthday image to mark his th year in  and he has taken a previous portrait picture of the duchess.The prince will spend his birthday attending the annual Remembrance Day Service at the Cenotaph.He will lay a wreath on the top step of the Cenotaph on the Queenrsquos behalf as she watches from the balcony of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office building.vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Wales lays a wreath during the Remembrance Sunday service at the Cenotaph Charles began placing one on his motherrsquos behalf in , with the change seen as a subtle sht of head-of-state duties.Buckingham Palace has said that the Queen will attend the annual wreath-laying service in Whitehall, which falls on November  this year, and honours Britainrsquos war dead.It comes as the -year-old monarch has missed several other events after being ordered to rest by royal doctors just over three weeks ago. She spent a night in hospital on October  undergoing preliminary tests.On Thursday, Charles reassured a bystander about the Queenrsquos health as he met people in Brixton.vw,vw,px, px"The Queen observing the Remembrance ceremony from the balcony of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office .removeCharles was greeted by crowds after an engagement for the Princersquos Trust in south London.One man asked him: ldquoPrince Charles. How is your mother Charles gave him an encouraging pat on the arm, and appeared to say: ldquoShersquos all right, thank you.The royal received an early birthday cake as he welcomed organisations that have been recognised by the Queenrsquos Awards for Enterprise to a reception at Windsor Castle on Wednesday.Jo Taylor, owner of Reach and Rescue, a company making telescopic rescue poles for emergency personnel, gave him the cake.Ms Taylor, whose company was recognised in the innovation category, said: ldquoThe prince laughed and said, lsquoYoursquove been doing your research on mersquo, and he slipped the card into his left pocket.Charles recently attended the Cop climate summit in Glasgow, where he told world leaders that ldquowe need to put our words and commitments into practice.Among the long-time environmentalistrsquos own efforts to reduce his carbon footprint is eating less meat and dairy products and converting his Aston Martin to run on cheese and wine byproducts..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Photo of Charles beaming on a bench marks his rd birthday

title: queen-attend-cenotaph-remembrance-sunday-service
story: The Queen will attend the Remembrance Sunday service at the Cenotaph, leading the nation in commemorating the war dead.The -year-old monarch has been under doctorsrsquo orders to rest for almost a month.The event will be given added poignancy by ato pre-pandemic numbers of participating veterans and military, as well as onlookers.The Prime Minister will be among senior politicians and members of the royal family laying a wreath at the war memorial in central London for the National Service of Remembrance.Boris Johnson said it was a moment to ldquocome together to remember those who sacriced everything in service of our country.He said: ldquoItrsquos a sacred ceremony that has endured for more than a century because we know the unpayable debt we owe those brave servicemen and women.ldquoWe know that for our tomorrow they gave their today.ldquoAnd we know that here at home and around the world, thousands of men and women in unorm still stand ready to defend our unity and our way of le, our values, and at a cost few among us would be willing to pay.vw,vw,px, px"Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer and Prime Minister Boris Johnson at the stripped-back National Service of Remembrance at the Cenotaph in  Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said it was ldquotime for us all to stop, reflect, and remember those millions of people from Britain and the Commonwealth who have kept us safe through their service and sacrice.He added: ldquoOur way of le, our values and our democracy are hard fought for through le-ending and le-changing sacrice.ldquoIt is that sacrice that has ensured we can enjoy the freedoms that we live by every day and that we must never forget.The Remembrance service in Whitehall willto normal this year, after the coronavirus pandemic limited the number of veterans and military and closed the ceremony to the public last year.Hundreds of servicemen and women will line up around the Cenotaph, and nearly , veterans will march past the war memorial, watched by large crowds..removevw,vw,px, px"The Queen observes last yearrsquos scaled-back service at the Cenotaph from a balcony at the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office building Buckingham Palace has said it was the Queenrsquos ldquofirm intention to attend the annual wreath-laying service in Whitehall.The monarch, who lived through the Second World War as a teenager, is head of the armed forces and attaches great importance to the poignant service and to commemorating the sacrices made by fallen servicemen and women.It comes as she has missed several other events after being ordered to rest by royal doctors just over three weeks ago, including the Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall on Saturday evening.She spent a night in hospital on October  undergoing preliminary tests.The Prince of Wales will lay a wreath on the top step of the Cenotaph on the Queenrsquos behalf as she watches from the balcony of a government building, as in previous years.vw,vw,px, px"The Prince of Wales lays a wreath during rsquos Remembrance Sunday service Chief of the defence staff General Sir Nick Carter said it was an ldquohonour to lay a wreath at the Cenotaph on behalf of ldquoall those who have lost their lives in the service of our country.He said: ldquoThey died to protect the free and open way of le that we enjoy today.ldquoOn Remembrance Sunday all members of the armed forces will reflect on this legacy, regardless of where and in what circumstances they are serving, sure in the knowledge that they now have the responsibility to uphold the values and standards that their forebears espoused.vw,vw,px, px"Rows of poppies on crosses laid out in the Field of Remembrance outside Westminster Abbey The Royal British Legion , the UKrsquos largest charity supporting the armed forces community which celebrates its centenary this year, said the march will include hundreds of young people from the Cadets, Guides and Scouts.ldquoIt is vital the torch of Remembrance is passed to younger generations and wersquore proud so many will be attending alongside veterans of all ages, said Bob Gamble, the RBLrsquos assistant director for commemorative events.He said: ldquoFor  years the Royal British Legion has led the nation in Remembrance to ensure the memory of those who have served and sacriced on our behalf is upheld.ldquoRemembrance is part of the fabric of society, reminding us of our shared history, and today it continues to unite people of all backgrounds, communities, and generations.ldquoThe poppy has been a symbol of Remembrance for  years, and itrsquos a fantastic feeling to be part of continuing the legacy. Learn more about the collectors who are ing to their communities for the #PoppyAppeal## https:t.co GFEfNgr#EveryPoppyCounts@ArmyMedServicespic GFXErdJymdash Royal British LegionNovember , The RBL has been selling poppies, a common sight on the Western Front which became a symbol of remembrance for those killed in the First World War, in the build-up to the day as part of its annual Poppy Appeal.A national two-minute silence will take place at am on Sunday to remember those who fought in past conflicts and paid the ultimate sacrice.Ceremonies will also take place at war memorials across the country, after being scaled back last year with the RBL advising the public to commemorate remotely by displaying a poppy in their window.Meanwhile, members of the royal family and the Prime Minister joined a crowd of thousands to pay tribute to all those who lost their lives in conflicts at the annual Festival of Remembrance on Saturday night.In a break with previous years, the Queen was not in attendance at the event which takes place at the Royal Albert Hall..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Queen to attend Cenotaph Remembrance Sunday service

title: insulate-britain-clampdown-measures-laid-parliament
story: New protest crackdown measures that could see Insulate Britain demonstrators jailed for causing major disruption are to be unveiled to Parliament.Under the changes due to be tabled on Monday, Insulate Britain protesters ndash dubbed ldquoirresponsible crusties by Prime Minister Boris Johnson ndash could face six months behind bars and slapped with an unlimited fine.The amendments to the Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill, which are due to be laid in the House of Lords, will also hand the police greater powers to tackle offenders who officers suspect could be about to block or glue themselves to roads, trains, planes and other vital infrastructure.The Home Secretary said it was ldquoright that those who ldquochoose to pursue a path of anti-social, dangerous disruption faced the prospect of a prison sentence as punishment.The Home Office said the current law, which sets the penalty at a maximum fine of pound,, was no longer an adequate deterrent for organisations ldquodetermined to cause widespread disruption and break the law.Officials said Insulate Britain had caused ldquomonths of public misery, including sparking large traffic jams, holding up ambulances and hospital patients, and preventing commuters from getting to work, by blocking major roads and motorways.Roads targeted by the group include the M around London, the M in Manchester and the A in Birmingham, among others.vw,vw,px, px"Home Secretary Priti Patel The department said that, in the first four weeks of protests by the environmentalists, the group cost the politan Police alone pound million in wasted police funds, with total arrests reaching nearly  to date.Home Secretary Priti Patel said: ldquoNobody should have unchecked rights to endanger the public ndash and themselves ndash while causing misery for millions in the name of protest.ldquoThere are numerous legitimate ways in which activists can peacefully campaign for meaningful change, and it is right that those who instead choose to pursue a path of anti-social, dangerous disruption should face the prospect of jail..removeldquoIt is totally unacceptable that police should be spending their days ungluing faces from dangerous roads. They should be in our communities protecting the vulnerable people who need them most.ldquoThatrsquos why our Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill is so necessary. The public expect everyone in Parliament to stand up for the hard-working, law-abiding majority, stand up for the police and back the Bill.vw,vw,px, px"Police are to be handed stronger powers to prevent disruptive protest as part of the amendments due before Parliament The clampdown on the ldquoguerrilla tactics of the likes of Extinction Rebellion and Insulate Britain were first put forward in September and cited again in the Home Secretaryrsquos speech to the Conservative Party conference last month.Other measures due to be unveiled on Monday will include allowing the police to stop and search people where there is a reasonable suspicion they are carrying items intended to cause disturbance by ldquolocking-on using glue or other means.Future amendments will also include bringing in ldquoserious disruption prevention orders, which will give the courts the power to prevent an inidual with a history of using disruptive measures from attending certain protests in future.Orders could apply to someone convicted of protest-related criminal offences such as blocking a motorway, or where there is evidence that they have contributed to similar such protests, the Home Office said..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Insulate Britain clampdown measures to be laid before Parliament

title: put-christmas-tree
story: It may only be November, but people are already preparing for Christmas and maybe even thinking about putting up the tree.The date for putting up the Christmas tree tends to y from family to family, with some opting for an early start to the festivities, while others wait right until the last minute.But did you know theres a traditional date for putting up your tree Heres everything you need to know about when you should be putting up your Christmas tree...When should Iput my Christmas tree up According to tradition in the UK, you should put your Christmas tree up around the beginning of advent, which is four Sundays before Christmas.This year, advent will start on November , however lots of people will choose to wait until December .Roman Catholic tradition on the other hand is at the other end of the spectrum - waiting until Christmas eve to put up the tree.The Queen finishes "dressing" her tree on Christmas eve, with all the members of the Royal family joining in as a festive family activity.While there are dferent traditions, it is of course completely up to you when you choose to put up your tree and start celebrating the festive season!What date should I take my Christmas tree down Again, according to tradition, you should take your tree down on the th day of Christmas, which is January .The first day of Christmas is unsurprisinglyDecember  and traditionally is followed by  further days of celebration.January  marks the beginning of the Christian holiday Epiphany.Superstition suggests it is "bad luck" to keep your decorationsup after this date.However last year many people around the country kept their Christmas lights up well into February to maintain some festive cheer during the post-Christmaslockdown.

title: scotland-v-moldova-channel-kick-off-time-watch-live-tv-tonight
story: Scotlandwill play Moldova tonight in the World Cup Qualiers marking their penultimate Group F match.Steve Clarkes side currently sit in second place with  points trailing Denmarkwho lead with  points.The top two teams from each group will qualy for the play-offs for the  Quatar WorldCup anda win tonight will secure Scotlands second place finish.The pressure may be on, but Scotland can come into the match with confidence having won - against Moldova in September.Of course, that match was slightly closer than anticipated and took place in front of a home crowd whereas tonights match is at Zimbru stadium in Moldova.Regardless, Scotland will look to close the deal to take them once step closer to the World Cup dream.Heres what you need to know about tonights match and how you can tune in...What time is kick-off for Scotland v Moldova Kick-off for Scotland v Moldova is at pm on Friday November .The match will take place at Zimbru stadium in Moldova, which is around a  hour flight from Scotland.How can I watch the Scotland v Moldova match on TV The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..Who is in the Scotland squad Steve Clarke has named a -player strong squad for the World Cup Qualiers.Goalkeepers:Craig Gordon , Jon McLaughlin , Liam Kelly .Defenders:Stephen ODonnell , Nathan Patterson , Jack Hendry , Grant Hanley , Scott McKenna , Liam Cooper ,Kieran Tierney , Andy Robertson .Midfielders:Billy Gilmour , Kenny McLean , Callum McGregor , Stuart Armstrong Stev, David Turnbull , John McGinn , Lewis Ferguson , Scott McTominay ..removeStrikers:Lyndon Dykes , Che Adams , Ryan Christie , Ryan Fraser , Kevin Nisbet .The starting line-up will be announced before the match later today.

story: Scotlandwill play South Africa in their third match of the rugbyautumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Australiain front of a home crowd, winning -in a title: send-letters-santa-royal-mail-year--
story: Lettersto Santa can be posted once again this year with Royal Mail, and senders will even receive a reply!Theres no need to try and sendletters up the chimney, just pop it in a post box instead.For -years, Royal Mail has been helping hundreds of thousands of children post their letters to Santa.Heres how you can send Santa letters this year...How to post letters to Santa this year...You can send your letters to Santa this year at the address:Santa Father Christmas,Santarsquos Grotto,Reindeerland,XM HQLetters should be sent by Friday December  to ensure time for response.Make sure to attachfull name and address so senders can receive a reply from Santa.The card from Santa will include a special note from the man himself and a recipe for a gingerbread Buddy the elf recipe.If you cant wait for the response, the card can be downloaded from the Royal Mail website.What are the last datesfor Christmas post Royal Mail is encouraging customers to shop early and post early for Christmas this year.Its latest recommended posting dates for mail to arrive in time for Christmas are:Saturday  Decembernd Classnd Class Signed ForRoyal Mail Tuesday  Decemberst Classst Class Signed ForRoyal Mail Thursday  DecemberSpecial Delivery Guaranteed

title: covid-scotland-need-passenger-locator-form-return-uk
story: Internationaltravel is getting easier after months of uncertainty, however did you know you still have to fill out a passenger locator form Before arriving in the UK, travellers must complete a form detailing where they have been and where they are travelling to.This applies to everyone coming to the UK from abroad, evenyou are only transiting through the country.Heres everything you need to know about filling in the form and travelling to the UK from abroad...What is the passenger locator form You must complete a passenger locator form within-hours before travelling to the UK.Yoursquoll need to show thisform when you check in to travelor board your plane, train or ferry to the UK.If you have not filled out the form, you could be denied travel.The form asks for details of where you have been, vaccination status and where you are going.What do I need to complete the form To complete the form yoursquoll need:your passport details or the travel document yoursquoll use when you arrive at the UK borderyour travel details, including times and datesthe address where you will stay in the UK booking reference numbers for any COVID- tests you must take after arriving in the UKthe invoice number for your quarantine hotel bookingyou need oneto say whether you are vaccinated and where you were vaccinatedYou can fill out your passenger locator form here.What are the current testing rules for ing to the UK from abroad England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are following a four nationsapproach to international travel, meaning the rules for all four countries are the same.If you are fully vaccinatedyou are still required to take a test within two days of arrival in the UK, however this can now be a lateral flow test instead of a PCR test as previously required.Lateral flow tests are cheaper than PCR tests.If you are not fully vaccinated, you must take a test before travelling to the UK, book and pay for tests for day and day  after arrival and quarantine for  days..removeYou will also be required to complete a passenger locator form.

title: leader october 22 2021
