title: green-scotland-can-read-investigation
story: From big-name polluters to Scotlandrsquos most deteriorating rivers and lochs, The Heraldrsquos exclusive, week-long investigation kicks off on Tuesday, October , to answer some of the crucial questions in the ongoing climate crisis.Hot off the back of the successfullsquoWho Runs Scotland rsquo series in July, no stone will be left unturned in The Herald and The Ferretrsquos joint bid to uncover wrongdoing, stimulate debate, and generate discussion.This special series will run in print and online all of this week, exclusively to our subscribers.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today.

title: hidden-case-ewan-forbes-zoe-playdon-reviewed-dani-garavelli
story: Zoeuml PlaydonBloomsbury, poundReview by Dani GaravelliTHE le story of Sir Ewan Forbes ndash a Scottish aristocrat and trans man who fought a bitter court battle over a title ndash is innately dramatic. Born in , the fourth child of John Forbes-Sempill, baronet of Craigie, Ewan was thought to be a girl at birth and christened Elisabeth. But from the earliest age, he identied as male. So pronounced was his masculinity that by the time he was six, his mother was encouraging family members to call him ldquoBenjie and consulting paediatricians about possible medical interventions.After a sometimes dficult adolescence and ious treatments, Elisabeth became Ewan. He qualied as a doctor, and began working as a GP in Alford, Aberdeenshire, with little controversy. When he fell in love with his housekeeper Isabella, known as Patty, his birth certicate was amended ndash as was possible back then ndash so he could marry her.Wedlock was one thing, though inheritance another. The rule of primogeniture decreed that when Forbesrsquos older brother William died in , the baronetcy should pass to the next male sibling. That ought to have been Ewan. But not everyone agreed. One cousin, John, mounted a legal challenge on the basis Ewan "is now, and has been all along, of the female sex".Zoeuml Playdonrsquos book, The Hidden Case of Ewan Forbes, recounts these events and, more importantly, the extraordinary ones that followed. Emeritus professor in medical humanities at the University of London, she stumbled across the legal challenge while fighting for trans equality in . She and some lawyers had taken a High Court action to allow trans people to once again amend their birth certicates. That right had been swept away by a precedent-setting case known as Corbett v Corbett in . Then, a judge dissolved the marriage between trans woman April Ashley and her husband Arthur Corbett on the grounds that Ashley had always been a man and could not alter her birth certicate.Playdonrsquos side lost the case, but remained mystied. They knew people had successfully altered their birth certicates in the past and could not understand what had prompted the change. But then one of the lawyers was contacted by Ashleyrsquos solicitor, Terrence Walton. He said that before going into court in , he had been called into the judgersquos chamber and shown a previous case, then sworn to secrecy.That case was Forbesrsquos. And now, Playdon is revealing the details Walton couldnrsquot. Preparation for the court battle had been traumatic. Forbes was subjected to intimate physical examinations by a specialist who pronounced him to have two X chromosomes and therefore to be genetically female. But then Forbes did something audacious. He told doctors a coughing fit had caused a ldquotesticle to suddenly descend. He performed his own "biopsy" and sent the specimen to a lab.Forbess claim was medically impossible he must have bought the testis sample and faked the biopsy. But it was impossible to disprove. Eventually, the judge found in his favour. Forbes gained the title and kept his marriage. But, according to Walton, the case had led to a "blanket ban" on altering future birth certicates because ldquothere are some interests it is more important to protect than the rights of the iniduals.The victory proved pyrrhic for Forbes, too. The widespread conviction that he had committed perjury affected his standing. He deregistered himself from the General Medical Council and became moody and irascible.The case of Ewan Forbes was a landmark, and kudos to Playdon for unearthing it. But her book is not without its problems. The first ndash not Playdonrsquos fault ndash is that a lack of first-hand material means we donrsquot get a feel for Forbes as a person. He never wrote in any detail about how it felt to be presented to the Queen as a ldquodebutante while sporting HRT-induced hair on his chin, or to have his genitalia the subject of legal speculation. There is no suggestion he ever embraced the role of trans campaigner.The reader, then, relies on Playdonrsquos ability to enter that imaginative space. But she has so fully embraced the role of trans campaigner, she sacrices nuance for polemic. Take her treatment of Forbesrsquos older sister Margaret. Margaret initially sided with John, providing a written statement to the effect that her brother had been brought up as a girl. Later she changed her mind but she died before she could alter her testimony.Playdon has no time for Margaret. She makes reference to her "deadnaming" Ewan. And, of course, Margaret was in the wrong. But it doesnrsquot take much fellow feeling to understand why she behaved as she did. As a lesbian, she was barred from marrying her own partner. Yet she watched Forbes change sex and marry his. In addition, the rule of primogeniture discriminates against women. Whether Forbes was male or female, she was the older sibling. No wonder she felt resentment. I would have liked to have seen that intersection of injustices properly acknowledged, and the emotional conflicts more fully explored.Instead, Playdon attempts to write a definitive history of transphobia, weaving reports and symposiums in and out of her account of Forbess le. Every line of thinking she agrees with is legitimate everything she disagrees with is ldquopseudo-medicine, which is not to say that she is wrong, just that the black-and-white way in which she presents her argument has the effect of undermining it.This is not helped by her comparison of the subtle sht in official policy on trans people to "the quiet bureaucratic process" that led to the Holocaust, or her habit of dismissing wholesale media representations of trans people such as Coronation Streets Haley Cropper.The irony is that a greater focus on the human story with all its sadnesses might have played to her advantage.At present in the UK, trans men and women still require a Gender Recognition Certicate to legally change sex and even those who obtain one cannot inherit a title. Playdonrsquos aim is to convince the reader of the virtues of self-identication. In the end, though, it was the ability to empathise with Forbess suffering, much more than her proselytizing, that left me wondering why society makes it so dficult for trans people to be themselves.

title: princess-switch-3-romancing-star---scotland-makes-cameo-netflix-festive-film
story: The Princess Switch : Romancing the Star.Wait, didnrsquot we watch that last year That was The Princess Switch: Switched Again. This is the third instalment in the Netflix festive romcom franchise.A brief recap, please.Well, the first movie, The Princess Switch, stars Vanessa Hudgens as Stacy, a Chicago baker who visits the fictional European country of Belgravia.Vanessa Hudgens in The Princess Switch : Romancing the Star. Picture: Mark Mainz NetflixShe meets Margaret, Duchess of Montenaro , who is her double and they switch places.The second film, The Princess Switch: Switched Again, sees Stacy and Margaret pull the switcheroo again with a third lookalike, scheming Lady Fiona , joining in the fun. The latest flick sees the trio track down a stolen relic.Anything  While the original movie was made in Romania, the subsequent films have been shot in Scotland. Keep your eyes peeled for locations, such as Newbattle Abbey College near Dalkeith and Hopetoun House in West Lothian.Vanessa Hudgens in The Princess Switch : Romancing the Star. Picture: Mark Mainz NetflixIs there a fourth lookalike Unlikely. As Hudgens herself has said: ldquoI would  per cent lose my mindI tried to add another me, even though it would probably be Scottish. I love that accent and it would be a great excuse to master the Scottish accent. But no, thatrsquos not happening.:Paul Murton is no stranger to the wilds of Scotland but whats his favourite place When can I watch The Princess Switch : Romancing the Star premieres on Netflix this Thursday.

title: brian-cox-scotland-place-social-democracy-seems-functioning-
story: lsquoBrian, your new autobiography reads rather well. Itrsquos poignant and heartfelt ndash considering yoursquore not very bright rsquoNot surprisingly, Cox takes less than a nano second to work up an ire, to offer at least a hint of the fearsome creature hersquos revealed all too often on stage and screen. ldquoAre you talking about yourself, I presume Indeed, not. "Let me explain." Or rather, let me grovel for a couple of minutes in the hope this interview doesnrsquot collapse before itrsquos begun."There is a line in the book, Brian, in which your mother once wrote to your prospective mother-in-law saying, Brianrsquos not awfully bright. But hersquos got a good heart. I was quoting Molly Cox ndash and attempting to highlight how our parents can be a little inappropriate at times. I realise you probably wrote this book at least a year ago, and some of the detail will have slipped to the outer edges of the mind. Sorry, Brian, I was trying to be funny."Thankfully, the penny drops and the Dundonian blood s to room temperature. ldquoAh, yes, I forgot about that, he says, laughing, perhaps in relief hersquos not having to converse with a self-destructive idiot. ldquoMy ma was trying to be kind. But sometimes the wording Scots mothers use isnrsquot exactly right.For sure. I tell him the tale of how I once had a parachute accident and a few days later, while I was in hospital, my mother told a friend I was going to be OK. She added: lsquoTherersquos very little sign of brain damage.rsquoCox laughs at this. Hard. I like him a lot for letting me off the hook. ldquoYes, Scots mothers do that. And they are wonderful.Brian Cox had a wonderful mother who worked hard to look after her five children in a two-roomed flat in Dundee. But she had serious mental health issues, no doubt exacerbated when Coxrsquos father, Chic, a shopkeeper, died when young Brian was just eight years old.For most of his early le, he was looked after by his older sisters and an aunt. ldquoYou donrsquot think about it at the time. You just get on with it. But what I didnrsquot realise until I wrote the book was that when yoursquore eight there is a certain resilience. What I also didnrsquot appreciate was that my brother, Charlie, who was  at the time, must have been really affected in terms of grief.He adds: ldquoI have a -year-old son now. And being a teenager is tough enough. When we think of teenage hormone attacks, we think of females. But we should also remember that male teenagers go through all levels of s***.Charlie ran off to the army. Young Brian endured an early le of eating scraps from the chippy. Surviving. Is it fair to say this early tragedy created a sense of detachment  And did that, perhaps, play a part in his becoming an actor, perhaps separating himself from the real world  ldquoYou know, I think you are absolutely right. In le, you sometimes have to find ways to protect yourself.He adds: ldquoItrsquos funny you should mention that detachment because I later came to realise that it led to a sense of absence growing up, and it has really been something Irsquove had to deal with.The actor, who has undergone therapy, admits he was absent a great deal during his first marriage to we Caroline, and lsquohad little affinity with the process of fatheringrsquo his two children. ldquoI still beat myself up about that. It was almost a medical fact. There was nothing I could do about it. But it takes over me sometimes. I still feel a sense of grief about relationships Irsquove had in the past, the break-ups with ladies Irsquove had. I have to acknowledge that this feeling of being absent is still with me yet try and move on. Itrsquos about the journey.Brian Coxrsquos lucky escape from poverty came about when he discovered Dundee Rep. Aged , this lsquorough-speaking urchinrsquo found work as the lowest assistant. But he loved the world, of sweeping up, banking cash, setting Lynn Redgraversquos stage wig in rollers. ldquoIt was a blessing. It was an egalitarian world where I was welcomed. Donrsquot get me wrong, I knew I was also a curiosity. [He mimics his old accent lsquoTalkinrsquo like that, ken.] But I couldnrsquot believe my luck and the kindness shown to me.Cox resolved to study acting and took himself off to LAMDA in London. And this career choice offered up a surrogate father in acting legend Fulton Mackay, who would later find TV fame as Mr Mackay in Porridge.ldquoHe was probably the most important man in my le. He had also gone into therapy because his mother died when he was young from diabetes, and his father travelled all over with the NAAFI. Fulton had no real home. And he shared all this knowledge with me.Cox offers a warm smile. ldquoI found in theatre the family I craved. And [that connection with other actors] continues. I also have this right now with the Succession family. I love all of them. Sure, there are moments, but I deeply adore them.Brian Coxrsquos acting ndash and le ndash story features a rainbow of colours. His journey from Dundee to RADA is full of passion, his tales of rep theatre companies illuminating. One minute hersquos appearing on stage as Captain Ahab in Moby Dickthe next hersquos sharing actor Linda Thorsonrsquos flat in New York with thousands of cockroaches. Or hersquos warding off dressing room advances from a fruity, very handy, Princess Margaret. He laughs when you suggest had the roles been reversed, he would have been taken to the Tower.Along the way the actor picked up major acclaim and theatre prizes such as two Olivier Awards. What emerges however is that Cox has never assumed technical greatness he has continually looked at technique and style. ldquoYes, and Fulton encouraged that need to improve. He was a great learner.But what of the rejection  Itrsquos also a world in which you can be turned down because you are too small, too tall, too heavy, too slight . . .you canrsquot ride a horse like Willie Carson . . . ldquoYes, itrsquos hard, but especially for females in the business. And Irsquove seen many who have been under siege at the hands of the likes of the horribleWeinstein. I have nothing but respect for those whorsquove survived this element of the business. But of course, the women had to keep it secret. They were under so much pressure not to reveal. But now they can.Cox speaks of egalitarianism in theatre. But he admits there were glass ceilings facing working class hopefuls. Scots, for example, could play army sergeants, but not officers. ldquoThatrsquos true. It goes back to the time when we lived in a feudal society, where everyone knew their place. We still have that. We still have monarchy.Brian Cox is most certainly a class warrior, but interestingly he supports teaching of Received Pronunciation, which was once forced upon working class students. ldquoThe thing about the sound of RP is that you have  vowel sounds you can choose from. And in standard accents, Scots, Irish or Welsh, there are only  vowels to choose from. It actually increases your range. So, itrsquos not a class thing at all. When you think of people such as [John] Gielgud or [Paul] Scofield, they had a tremendous range. And it was really important for me to learn clarity.He adds: ldquoOne of the problems in movies these days is there is not enough clarity. Too much mumbling. Brando mumbled in Streetcar, of course, but his Marc Anthony revealed immense clarity.Brian Cox became, undoubtably, one of the greatest theatre actors of his generation. But he decided to side line that part of his career in a bid to conquer Hollywood. Does he regret moving to the States and becoming a multi-millionaire film star, living in New York, working with the likes of Brad Pitt in Troywhen he could have been appearing at the Royal Court for pound a week ldquoNo, he says, laughing. ldquoAnd remember, for me the cinema was essentially the proletarian art form. Thatrsquos where I first saw Albert Finney who gave me hope and possibility. In Dundee we had  cinemas, which showed double features and I could see eight films a week. I could see Danny Kaye and James Dean and Brando. And the films did have a classless element to them. I always knew thatrsquos where I wanted to go.Itrsquos no real surprise that Cox has made such a success of his film career. He brings with him a weight, a confidence and a toughness. He has little hesitation in telling directors what he thinks of their instruction. ldquoWe Celts came from Europe and settled in Ireland and Scotland. We have a tough character.Invoking his cultural history sees the actor leap onto his political soapbox with such ease yoursquod never guess he had -year-old knees. He expounds for at least a few minutes about his incredible disappointment with Labour, how he was appalled by Tony Blairrsquos decision to invade Iraq and the demise of social democracy in the UK. ldquoI used to think the Scots Nats were a joke party but now I think the only place that social democracy seems to be ing is my home country. So perhaps thatrsquos where my allegiance lies.Does he believe independence can contend with economic realities  ldquoThose realities are now being defined by the condition of the planet, he says. ldquoThatrsquos why kids really are the future. Wersquove taken so much for granted and we canrsquot anymore. My big problem is that I fly. When Irsquom playing Logan Roy, I can be in the likes of Dubrovnik next week and I have to get there. Wersquore on the horns of a horric dilemma. And Russia and China wonrsquot come to the party.And even our friends the Australians who insist on mining coal. Arenrsquot they a set of selfish drongos  ldquoYoursquore right there, pal. And Irsquom also intolerant of America when it comes to coal, because it doesnrsquot make any sense. The government is behaving like frat night in a minor university.Brian Cox calls it as he sees it. He certainly isnrsquot backwards about coming forwards about the movie stars he doesnrsquot rate. Cox adores the likes of Alan Rickman but hersquos not a huge Michael Caine fan, although he admits Caine is ldquoan institution.Edward Norton is ldquoa pain in the a***. Steven Segal however is up there on the Hopeless list. And he turned down the chance to star alongside Johnny Depp in Pirates of the Caribbean because Depprsquos acting is panto.But does he feel perhaps his criticisms went a little too far  ldquoYes, thatrsquos a very good question and Irsquom planning to write an addendum. Irsquove been getting a lot of brouhaha, in particular from Johnny Depp fans. But itrsquos also made me think I want to put a perspective on things. Yes, I have called people an ass**** in the book, but then I realised that this referred to a time.ldquoSo, what Irsquom going to do for the American publication, is write that there is a possibility that people can change.Cox admits the business can cause allow people to behave very badly. ldquoYou can,yoursquore not very careful, lose the plot. And you do. During rehearsals for his first play in New York, he remembers asking the stage manager to fetch him a cup of tea. "He looked at me with absolute astonishment and said, Why dont you get your own tea  And I thought, Yes, absolutely right. Why dont I get my own tea "He adds: ldquoBut we should allow for the fact that sometimes we go through a dark tunnel ndash and hopefully come out the other side of it. There may have been something extraordinary going on in actors lives which impacts upon their performance.The theme of the book appears to be an actor in search of an identity  Is this fair  ldquoOh, yes, he agrees. ldquoI feel the search to be an on-going process. You really never stop. Yoursquore always weighing up the good stuff and the crap that goes on around you. And you spend your le trying to get a balance.He grins. ldquoAndyoursquore a Gemini like me, itrsquos doubly hard.And me, Brian. ldquoWhat  Yoursquore a Gemini as well  Oh, yes.He breaks into a loud laugh. ldquoWell, as a fellow Gemini yoursquoll know exactly what Irsquom talking about. We have this side of personality that says lsquof*** them.rsquo And then therersquos the other side that says lsquoOh, no. We have to consider this opinion.rsquoHe becomes even more exercised. Not Logan Roy angry at all, but certainly Agamemnon loud and commanding.ldquoYou know, Brian, therersquos a constant dialogue in my head. My whole le has been about this, with my head battling with the idea of what makes right and wrong. And the opposite sides of my head canrsquot agree a lot of the time.Perhaps it has helped make him he actor he is  Take Logan Roy, for example. He has real angularity. Hersquos a man conflicted. ldquoYou know. You understand, he says.I do. And I now know not to suggest actors may be a bit dim.Putting the Rabbit in the Hat, My Autobiography by Brian Cox. Published by Quercus, poundKey dates in Brian Coxrsquos calendarbull . Born in Dundeebull . Began working at Dundee Rep as lsquoan assistant to the assistant.rsquobull . Cox was one of the founders of the Royal Lyceum in Edinburgh.bull . Made his first television appearance in The Wednesday Play.bull . He made his debut in Londonrsquos West End.bull . Played the Duke of Burgundy opposite Sir Lawrence Olivier in King Leer.bull . Awarded an Olivier for his role in Rat in The Skull.bull . He played the first on-screen Hannibal Lecter in Manhunter.bull . Picked up his second Olivier for his starring role in Titus Andronicus.bull . Starred as King Lear.bull . Appeared in both Braveheart and Rob Roybull : Cox landed an Emmy nomination for his guest appearance in TV sitcom Frasier.bull . Played William Stryker in X: X- Men United.bull . Cox starred as Bob Servant in Neil Forsythrsquos Dundee-based sitcom.bull . Golden Globe winner for his lead role in Succession.

title: covid-scotland-seven-10-senior-doctors-plan-retire-early-pandemic
story: Graeme Eunson, chair of the BMArsquos Scottish consultantsrsquo committee, said a potential exodus of the countryrsquos most experienced doctors threatens to ldquoseriously undermine attempts to clear the waiting list backlog and derail training for younger medics.The warning comes after a survey by the trade union found that  per cent of consultants over  are considering voluntary early retirement, with half planning to reduce their working hours from next year.: Should doctors quit the NHS over punitive tax measures Dr Eunson, a consultant paediatrician in NHS Borders, said most consultants were ldquoprepared to stick at it for this winter and while we remain in pandemic, but he expects to see a surge in departures from .He said: ldquoItrsquos driven by several factors, the biggest of which is the pension tax issue which is - insanely - still driving senior clinicians and other staff out of the NHS earlier than they otherwise would have planned to.ldquoThe problem with that is that workforce planning is based on the number of people we have coming in at the bottom meeting the number of people leaving at the end, andyou are losing five years of a consultant career - and didnrsquot factor that in  years ago when you were planning intakes to medical school - then yoursquore going to start seeing these gaps.ldquoYou donrsquot have the specialists there to train the young doctors coming through, and you donrsquot have the people experienced enough to replace the senior consultants whorsquore leaving.ldquoThese were going to be the people wersquore depending on to get through the backlog of work, so thatrsquos going to be one of the big issues.ldquoBut for many small units where you may only have one or two people doing very specialist things, especially in areas like the Borders or Inverness or the Western Isles, losing one person can be the dference between a safe, sustainable service and a service that collapses.ldquoRetirement is one part, but % of the consultants we surveyed said they are planning on reducing their clinical sessions in the next year, and therersquos not the ability of those left behind to suck up the extra work because theyrsquore exhausted too.ldquoIf therersquos no solution to the pension tax issue, then people are just not going to have any incentive to stick with it - theyrsquore burnt out and itrsquos costing them a fortune to keep working.Dr Graeme EunsonDr Eunson said he was aware of one senior medic in Scotland who had paid pound, in pension tax over the past five years in addition to income tax and pension contributions.Recent UK figures indicate that the number of NHS doctors taking early retirement has tripled over the past decade, with Graham Crossley of wealth management experts Quilter blaming ldquoeye-watering pensions tax bills for ldquo[disincentivising] doctors to take on extra hours at a time when the health service is creaking.Many are reportedly turning to financial advisors for help after receiving five- or six-figure tax bills unexpectedly.The long-runnning problem relates to the NHS defined benefit system, which means that any growth in salary can translate into a large perceived growth in pension contribution.: Whats really behind the worst winter crisis facing Scotlands NHS Most workers are allowed to save pound, a year into their pension tax-free, but for higher earners this tapers down to just pound - above which they begin to trigger a tax bill.Chancellor Rishi Sunak sought to ameliorate the issue in the March  Budget by raising the salary at which this taper threshold kicks in from pound, to pound,, but a change in working patterns during the pandemic - including consultants working extra shts - has tipped many more into the bracket for high charges.ldquoFor most people staying on longer doesnrsquot get you a better pension, it doesnrsquot get you more money, it just brings you larger and larger tax bills each year," said Dr Eunson.ldquoAt the moment, all people have is the option to refuse to take on extra responsibilities or to reduce their hours below  sessions a week.Chancellor Rishi Sunak raised the taper threshold from pound, to pound, in March A similar initiative is already in place in some English NHS trusts, and the Welsh government has written to its health boards encouraging them to pursue this option.Dr Eunson said this would give senior medics a "powerful incentive to delay retirement".: Warning social care in Scotland at very real risk of collapse this winterA spokeswoman for the Scottish Government said its powers to resolve the issue are ldquoseverely limited as pension taxation is reserved to Westminster.She added: ldquoWe wrote to the Chancellor of the Exchequer on  June  asking for such consideration to be given to the current pension taxation regime to help ensure that health workers in Scotland can fully contribute to our recovery efforts. We will continue to press UK Ministers to give due consideration to this matter.

title: gamers-travel-back-time-life-pict-scotland-1-300-years-ago
story: Now a new collaboration between tabletop roleplaying game designers and archaeologists will give modern Scots a flavour of what it was like to live, hunt, haggle and survive in the land of the Picts.The new Dungeons  Dragons style game, Carved in Stone, will take players on a quest rooted in th century historical fact, designed to help players both indulge in fantasy fun while learning more about le in Scotland , years ago.Read more:Swan takes flight as pub rises from ashes to lt village fortunesIt is being developed by Edinburgh-based game design company Dungeons on a Dime and the Society of Antiquaries of Scotlandrsquos Dig It! project, which is primarily funded by Historic Environment Scotland and aims to bring archaeology in Scotland to a wider audience.Itrsquos hoped the game will appeal to heritage enthusiasts of all ages and the thriving global roleplaying game community.Game is a chance to step back in time. Image credit Olivia Rea.Tabletop roleplay gamesare collaborative storytelling games in which players take on the role of characters in the story. Typically, one personmdashthe Game Master or Narratormdashmanages the lsquoworldrsquo and the challenges, while the players explore and problem-solve.Read more:St Kildarsquos archaeologist lives le on the edge with never-ending list of repairsOne of the most famous and elaborate examples is Dungeons  Dragons, which emerged in the s and has gained a cult following. The game, which involves players collaborating to fight villains and pursue quests, appeared in the hit TV show Stranger Things and is set to be turned into a film starring Chris Pine, Sophia Lillis and Bridgertonrsquos Regeacute-Jean Page.In most TTRPGs, all players need is dice and a system of game rules. Setting books, such as Carved in Stone, describe the world in which the adventure takes place, and can be used with any TTRPG rules system, including Dungeons and Dragons.Carved in Stone takes players to a period just after the Battle of Nechtansmere in  CE, when the Picts defeated the Northumbrians to become the leading political force in what is now Scotland.Carved in Stone, with its historically accurate details, will enable narrators to create adventures in which players explore the landscape, meet members of society, and create their own stories.The cover image of Carve in StoneDr Jeff Sanders, Project Manager of Dig It!, said the intention was to use role play games as a vehicles to help people explore, enjoy and learn about Scotlandrsquos past.ldquoWe chose to set it in Scotland at the end of the th century because so much recent work that has completely changed our understanding of this medieval Scotland, he added.ldquoItrsquos a fun, exciting and dferent world that is starting to resemble the Scotland we know but is still a long way from it too.ldquoMost roleplay games are set in a fantasy world, but this is set in real world setting.The setting is built around the aftermath of the Battle of Nechtansmere, when King Mac Bridei, a charismatic but ruthless figure who remains in the background of the Carved in Stone setting, defeated the Northumbrian threat and set the wheels in motion for a unied Scotland.Excavation at a Pictish fort at Burghead, MorayPlayers must prepare for the Kingrsquos arrival in a small village where a funeral is to take place, requiring a series of quests to gather necessary items.ldquoThey will have to get their booze from the monks, get cows and embark on a hunt, he adds. ldquoThe game allows us to introduce all the core themes of Pictish le: subsistence, the economy, farming, technology and Scotlandrsquos place in the world.ldquoThe Romans have been gone for several centuries, but trade networks are there, so Scotland is still importing from the continentyoursquore a high-status Pict, you will want to dress in colourful silks and drink fine wine.The book provides historically accurate details about elements of le at the time that could help or hinder players during their adventures. However its developers say it avoids perpetuating stereotypical images of le at the time, such as naked Pictish warriors who covered their bodies in blue tattoos.Concept art and layouts have been created and a new crowdfunding campaign was launched on Kickstarter yesterdaywhich aims to raise pound, to bring the game to fruition.If successful, it will be available for purchase with copies donated to School Library Outreach, Glasgowrsquos school library service, which has provided literacy and education advice on the project.The text will later be released digitally under a Creative Commons license which means anyone will be able to access, use and remix it for free.Dan MacLean, Community Engagement and Finds Specialist at the Northern Picts Project, said: ldquoWe are currently experiencing an archaeological revolution in terms of understanding the st millennia CE, particularly the Pictish kingdoms.ldquoExcavations and project work by universities , commercial companies, community groups and museums are writing a new and exciting chapter in Scottish history.Roleplaying games boomed during the pandemic, as players took tabletop versions online, opening up the opportunity to interact with gamers across the world.The games have been linked to boosting playersrsquo social skills, creative thinking and problem solving, while games based in fact, such as Carved in Stone, offer an educational element.Lizy Simonen, Learning Assistant at Glasgow Le , said: ldquoRoleplaying games are a mix of literature, storytelling, improvised theatre and visual arts. They bring people together to tell stories, problem solve and challenge each othersrsquo imaginations.ldquoResearch shows that these games have exceptional benefits, aiding in the development of identity and unity across minority and majority groups, teaching vital social skills and engaging vulnerable people. This is an exciting part of Scotlandrsquos story and we are looking forward to helping tell it.Brian Tyrrell, Director at roleplay game developers Dungeons on a Dime, said itrsquos hoped the game will bring greater understanding of the ersity, landscape and way of le in Scotland in the th century.ldquoHistory and archaeology are conversations between the past and present. For too long the same perspectives have dominated that conversation, interpreting evidence to reflect their own interests.ldquoWe hope it can help inspire more people to examine their past critically and find that there was always a place for them in history where they previously thought there was none.

title: red-deer-pest-photographer-neil-mcintyre-wants-restore-glory
story: ldquoThat stag, says McIntyre, ldquowas quite cheeky and would come and have a look. I felt he was curious about me. He always had that look. He moved around with a group of about twenty stags that lived away up the head of a glen and most of them keep their distance a little bit. But he would always come that bit closer and he was always one that had that curious look on his face.Red deer are one of the photographers big loves, which is why he has followed up his book, On The Trail Of Red Squirrels, with another on these imposing animals. That love started young. McIntyrersquos father was a gamekeeper and deerstalker who took him out with him sometimes while he was working in Perthshire, and later the Highlands. Always, the young boy noticed, there was something about the deer that stood out more than other animals. He recalls on one occasion, as a small child, on a visit to a nearby estate, he came very close to a stag for the first time.ldquoI had never realised how large the deer were, he writes, ldquountil one was standing right in front of me. His shoulders were above my head ndash of course a full-grown stag would be far taller than a six-year-old-boy, but seeing it was overwhelming. His breath seemed like smoke in the freezing air. The head, antlers bigger than his shoulders, dipped back and forth over the food. I remember holding up my hands and realising that one antler would be longer than my arm. It would have taken both my childish hands to wrap around it.The stag wasnrsquot there for very long but it made an impression. ldquoI remember," he says,"looking up at this huge, impressive stag, and meeting his dark brown eye. I remember losing sight of him in the crowd as more and more deer ran down from the hills to join the feast. I remember longing to reach out and touch their magnicence, and my fatherrsquos gentle warning, lsquoTheyrsquore wild, not for trusting.rsquoEver since then, he says, he has been fascinated with red deer. Though McIntyre didnrsquot become a gamekeeper like his father, or his brother, or his nephew, he became another type of stalker, a wildle photographer. He recalls there were only a few times that he shot deer himself, though for him, growing up in the stalking family he did, that was very much a rite of passage.ldquoI never wanted to be a deerstalker myself, he says. ldquoI have shot a few deer obviously, being brought up with it, but from a very early age I would rather take their picture. But Irsquove experienced it and done it and thatrsquos maybe not a bad thing. Itrsquos let me see how itrsquos done. Itrsquos not as easy as some people make out. It does involve quite a lot of skills to do it properly.He shot a couple of hinds when his father was doing the hind cull, and in his late teens even shot a stag. ldquoAnd that was it," he recalls. "Once Irsquod done it, I didnrsquot particularly want to.In recent decades, the deer has become a target in the firing line of another mission: the fight against climate change and bioersity loss. Its numbers, ious reports have said, must be controlled because of the ways in which deer browse on young trees and prevent reforestation. Its an issue that seems all the more potent in the wake of COP, as we strive to hit national targets.In  a report was published by the Scottish Governmentrsquos independent Deer Working Group, which delivered a range of recommendations including phasing out the use of lead ammunition to cull deer, modernisation of existing deer legislation, the development of robust deer management plans and enhanced monitoring of deer numbers.Earlier this year, when Ben Macpherson, then Minister for Rural Affairs and the Natural Environment, announced the policy proposals, he made clear what the strategy was about. ldquoAs the scale of tackling climate change and the bioersity crisis increases, and the measures needed to address these challenges become ever more necessary, it is evident that a signicant stepping-up of deer management efforts are required.In , when the Red Deer Commission was set up it was estimated that the speciesrsquos population was around ,. In more recent years the population has been estimated at around , to ,.McIntyre writes in his book, ldquoEveryone has their own ideas about what would be a stable population for red deer across the country. My research shows that in  , a total of , red deer were culled from an estimated Scottish population of ,ndash,. Contrary to what some would like you to think, this population is in decline. Some would say that not only is this a good thing but they hope it will continue, suggesting that a more stable number is somewhere in the region of , total population. That implies a horric number of red deer would have to die.He remains a fierce advocate for the red deer and a critic of the stronger deer control measures and some of the working grouprsquos recommended policies. Above all, he wants to bring back love and respect to the deer. ldquoThat was a big part of doing the book, he says, ldquoto try to get some respect back for them, because sadly over the last literally two decades their stature so to speak has been much maligned, reduced to nothing more than a pest in some peoplersquos mind.This defence is partly informed by his own family history. He comes from a line of men involved in the deer business and has observed the way their management has changed over the years. ldquoMy grandfather broke in deer ponies after the war, he says. ldquoThe Highland ponies were very much in use for getting the carcasses off the hill. And my grandfather used to train them. That was his job for Glen Artney down near Comrie. He used to get train loads of Highland garrons in and they would all get trained up to carry deer. They would get sent out all over Scotland to ious dferent estates.By the time McIntyre himself arrived in the world, his grandfather had already finished up work in that business. ldquoHe had been kicked so many times with the horses he became quite crippled - so he sort of retired from that a bit earlier than he would normally have done just because of so many kicks he had in the legs from working with the horses.It was, he recalls, by going out with his father, by listening to him and watching the deer, he would learn about their habits and the best way to approach them - which would stand him in good stead in his career as a wildle photographer. ldquoThese things became almost instinctive and not something I really thought about.Coal, steam, empire and COP : Glasgows emissions storyIt also gave him an appreciation of the way of le of the gamekeeper and deerstalker, which has made him an advocate, even in times when a lot of the drive in conservation and rewilding is towards dramatically cutting deer numbers, even zero tolerance, in order to promote forest regeneration."Therersquos nobody," he says, "really has more respect and admiration for the deer than a proper deerstalker. They do their job in a very considered way - and I think they probably know more about deer than anybody.McIntyre is a reminder that urban advocates of rewilding, like myself, can have their view of the deer, but they donrsquot really know them, or the impact they have, like he does. He is also an advocate for the rural worker, who comes in many dferent forms, and for their continued existence on the land. Some of his arguments remind me of those of crofters, who speak for a kind of nature restoration that still allows room for people in the landscape.His love of the deer is clear in his photography. One of his most prized shots is of a stag shaking off water in the winter. ldquoThe deer obviously spend quite a bit of time in the rain," he says. "And you get stags or hinds when theyrsquore lying down for a long time,itrsquos pouring down theyrsquoll just become like a big sponge. You can almost guarantee the very first thing theyrsquoll do when they stand up is shake and you get this amazing plume of water comes off them. Their head stays almost motionless, but their whole body twists and this fantastic spray of water comes off.Its also clear from his writing how intimately he has got to know the deer. He writes, for instance, about how they struggle in spring, describes their rolling in the peat, the way that hinds and stags live separate lives until mating season, the spectacle of the rut. ldquoOn one occasion, he recalls, ldquoI was on the Rothiemurchus Estate and could hear stags roaring above me. I was about fty yards from where I needed to be to see them when I heard two crashing together ndash a sound not unlike the clash of wooden swords. I knew immediately that it must be antlers locking together. Desperate to witness this battle, still unsighted, I ran the last fty yards until I could peer cautiously over the knoll to see them. The light was poor and the photographs are not among my best but the spectacle was amazing: the sound and the power of two stags locked together, pushing at each other."What McIntyre is most critical of is the zero tolerance approach to deer adopted by some estates. ldquoThere are several rewilding estates that have followed that strategy, he says. ldquoIt suits their agenda. They want full scale natural regeneration, and therersquos no getting away from the fact there has been over-grazing, and theyrsquove adopted this policy which is how theyrsquove managed to get such prolic regeneration. But that has resulted in the deer virtually being wiped out of these areas. His anger is clear. ldquoItrsquos not management. They dress it up, theyrsquore very careful with their words, theyrsquore not stupid these people. Theyrsquoll say things like wersquore increasing deer cull numbers or wersquoll increase the management, but what they actually mean is itrsquos zero tolerance. Anditrsquos a deer itrsquos shot regardless of what age or sex. Itrsquos not about selecting animals. The deer has just become like a pest.Among the recommendations of the working group report of which McIntyre is critical, is the removal of the close season for males, so that they could be shot at any time, and reducing theof the female close season. ldquoThatrsquos reducing them to an even lower status than they are now. The impact would be, I think, quite catastrophic. It means deer can be shot any time.The question of to what degree red deer numbers need to be controlled, and how to control them, is one that has exercised a great many estate managers, environmentalists and conservationists. I have long been aware of the debate and the controversy around it, and have spoken to many out there who would argue against McIntyre. Even Simon King, writing the foreword of Mcintyrersquos book, notes that they do not agree on the matter of deer management.Im sceptical too, and nervous, about promoting a stepback from deer control at such a critical point in our history, in the midst of a climate and bioersity crisisin which forms of rewilding, to which large populations of deer are no friend, arebeing seen as an answer.: Rewild Scotland: "Beavers in all rivers. Lynx and wolf back.Nevertheless, theres also something I appreciate about McIntyrersquos fierce defence of the deer. I too have felt sad about the way in which those animals which have prolerated because of the way we humans have shaped the landscape, have become themselves demonised.Anti-deer sentiment, he writes, ldquoseems to have been growing over the years. Forestry and red deer have always been in conflict because of the supposed damage the deer do to trees. However, the rewilding movement, which has been gaining support in recent years, is even more averse to deer.Whatever strategy we take in terms of their control and management, I dont think we humans will ever stop admiring the red deer, and in particular its mature stag. Its asthat response to their presence and physicality is built into us. McIntyres photographs are testimony to their beauty and magnicence. Catch sight of a stag on the hill, or in one of his photographs, and it takes your breath away.Chasing the Deer: The Red Deer Through The Seasons by Neil McIntyre is published by Sandstone pressWe want to bring you the best The Herald has to offer every day. For just pound for two months, you can instantly read your favourite writers including Susan Swarbrick, Teddy Jamieson, Alison Rowat, Mark Smith, Vicky Allan, Russell Leadbetter and Barry Didcock, as well as Ron Mackenna, Rab McNeil, and the famous Herald Diary.When you head over to our subscriptions page yoursquoll see three options:bull       Our Premium subscription, for pound. per weekbull       Our Premium Plus subscription, for less than pound. per weekbull       Our Print Only subscription, which could save you %you enjoy buying the paper.Our special offer can be found under the ldquoPremium Plus plan under the option of pound for two months, then pound. monthly afterwardsyou decide to stay with us.Subscribe to The Herald and dont miss a single word from your favourite writers by clicking here

title: cop26-coal-fossil-fuel-subsidy-phase-out-call-survives-new-draft-text
story: The latest draft, published more than  hours after the UN climate summit in Glasgow was due to have finished, also requests countries ldquorevisit and strengthen their  emissions-cutting targets by the end of .This is seen as key to keeping the goal of limiting global warming to .C, beyond which the worst impacts of extreme weather and rising seas will be felt, within reach, although it does not specically refer to the .C goal.:Carbon footprint in Glasgow expected to be twice as much as last summitIt requests countries revisit the targets ldquoas necessary to align with the Paris Agreement temperature goal by the end of , taking into account dferent national circumstances.In the Paris Agreement in , countries committed to limit temperature rises to ldquowell below C and try to limit them to .C to avoid the most dangerous impacts of storms, droughts, crop failures, floods and disease.Scientists have warned that keeping temperature rises to .C requires global emissions to be cut by % by , and to zero overall by mid-century.But despite countries being required to update their action plans, known as nationally determined contributions, for emissions cuts up to  in the run-up to Glasgow, the latest pledges leave the world well off track to meet the goal.Therefore, countries are under pressure to come up with a deal in Glasgow that will see them rapidly increase their ambition for emission cuts in the s to stop the .C goal slipping out of reach as well provide the finance for developing countries to cope with the crisis.It also urges developed countries to at least double their collective provision of climate finance to help developing nations adapt to climate change, from  levels by .:Huge crowds of protesters take to Glasgow streets to call for climate actionThe historic reference to coal and fossil fuel subsidies has survived into the latest draft of the ldquocover decision text for an overarching deal that countries are hoping to strike in Glasgow, despite expected pushback from some big producer and emitter nations.It is the first time a climate change agreement of this kind specically mentions coal or fossil fuels.It calls on countries to accelerate technology and policies to sht towards low emission energy systems, by scaling up clean power generation and energy efficiency, including accelerating efforts towards the phase-out of unabated coal power and inefficient fossil fuel subsidies.But it also recognises the need for support towards a ldquojust transition, seen as important to protect those who might be hit by job losses or higher costs from the sht to clean energy.

title: glasgow-city-council-calls-commuters-keep-cop26-traffic-reduction
story: Glasgow City Council has said that traffic volumes dropped considerably during the international gathering as roads were closed off and vehicle access to the city centre became limited.Now the local authority want people to travel more by public transport, bike or on foot and help drive down fuel emissions further.Ahead of the international climate summit, multiple Glasgow roads were shut to close off the area surrounding the venue hosting thousands of delagates and world leaders.Now that the closures are coming to an end, Glasgow City Council is suggesting that there has been a  per cent reduction of traffic volume in the city during Cop.They think that this sort of practice will helpGlasgowrsquos drive towards net-zero.A Glasgow City Council spokesperson said: ldquoDuring the course of the COP climate change conference we have seen a  per centreduction in the volume of traffic."It is very encouraging that people visiting Glasgow and people who live and work here followed the pre-conference advice to leave the car at home and use public transport or walk or cycle instead."It also shows the effectiveness of the extensive pre-conference information campaign we carried out and the measures we put in place to manage the traffic.ldquoThis change in behaviour is very welcome and exactly the kind of thing that we would encourage as part of Glasgowrsquos drive to have net zero emissions by .:Campbeltown latest area to receive Scottish government climate fundingCity officials are now encouraging the same behaviourwhich they claim is the reason for the reduction. They suggest thatwalking, cycling and using public transport instead of travellingby caris the reason for the reduction.The call comes on the same day that the closures come to an end in the city.The road between Minerva Street andWest Greenhill Placere-opened at am this morning, but the more major Glasgow roads which have caused signicant travel disruption will remain closed until Monday.COP has caused a headache for many Glasgow motorists over the last few weeks. The Clyde Expressway has been shut for nearly three weeks and drivers have faced major ersions, some as long as five miles.Monday will see the Clyde Expressway and M junction  at Anderston back open for public use. The three mile stretch of dual carriageway which usually has thousands of vehicles pass through every day will help ease congestion on the M.There are also several other roads re-opening in Glasgow onNovember , and other closures will finish throughout the week with the final road re-opening on November .

title: cop26-glasgow-climate-pact-watered-down-last-minute-changes
story: Ministers and negotiators at the UN summit in Glasgow have also sent a signal on the sht away from the worlds dirtiest fuel, with a deal calling for efforts to escalate the "phase down" of unabated coal, as well as the phasing out of inefficient fossil fuel subsidies.The Glasgow Pact was watered down at the last minute - following a push by India and China - from escalating the "phase out" of unabated coal, to "phase down", prompting angry responses from European and vulnerable countries.But it is the first explicit mentions of fossil fuels in a UN climate agreement.Read more:COP: Warning of Glasgow Climate Pacts historic failure in closing gap on .CThe last-minute proposal was put forward by India after frantic negotiations between the US, EU, China and India and the UK presidency of the Cop talks.US Special Envoy for Climate John Kerry during the overrun sessionCop President Alok Sharma was forced to apologise for the way in which the change happened, and seemed briefly close to tears.Before a series of decisions were gavelled through, he told the delegates: "The choices that you are set to make are vitally important."They launch a decade of increasing ambition across mitigation, adaptation, finance and loss and damage, marking the road to keeping .C within reach, achieving the global goal on adaptation, delivering on the  billion US dollar goal and setting the new collective quantied goal on climate finance."Read more:COP: Climate activists hold ceremony of grief in GlasgowThe overall deal aims to keep limiting global warming to .C above pre-industrial levels "alive" or within reach, in the face of a huge gap between the action countries are taking and what is needed to meet the goal.In the wake of the "Glasgow Pact" being gavelled through - more than  hours after the official finishing time of the conference - there were warnings that the .C goal was "on le support".The pact requests countries revisit and strengthen their  national climate action targets "as necessary to align with the Paris Agreement temperature goal by the end of , taking into account dferent national circumstances".COP talks overranIn the Paris Agreement in , countries committed to limit temperature rises to "well below" C and try to limit them to .C to avoid the most dangerous impacts of storms, droughts, crop failures, floods and disease.Scientists have warned keeping temperature rises to .C requires global emissions to be cut by % by , and to zero overall by mid-century.But despite countries being required to update their action plans, known as nationally determined contributions, for emissions cuts up to  in the run-up to Glasgow, the latest pledges leave the world well off track to meet the goal.So countries have been under pressure to come up with a deal in Glasgow that will see them rapidly increase their ambition for emission cuts in the s to stop the .C goal slipping out of reach, as well as provide the finance for developing countries to cope with the crisis.Alok Sharma, President of COP, announced the Glasgow PactThe deal has measures on finance for poorer and more vulnerable countries to develop cleanly, cope with climate impacts and address the loss and damage they face from climate-related storms, floods, droughts and rising seas.The final agreement urges developed countries to at least double their collective provision of climate finance to help developing nations adapt to climate change, from  levels, by .There was also agreement on finalising key parts of the "Paris rulebook", on areas such as establishing carbon markets which have been outstanding since the climate treaty was agreed in .Responding to the decisions, Greenpeace International executive director Jenner Morgan said: "Its meek, its weak and the .C goal is only just alive, but a signal has been sent that the era of coal is ending. And that matters."Amanda Mukwashi, chief executive of Christian Aid, said: "We were told that Cop was the last best chance to keep .C alive, but its been placed on le support."Rich nations have kicked the can down the road and with it the promise of the urgent climate action people on the front line of this crisis need."

title: cop26-glasgow-pact-mean-agreed
story: What has been agreed The deal requests countries revisit and strengthen their  national climate action targets so they are in line with the Paris Agreement goal of keeping warming to "well below" C and pursuing efforts to limit temperature rise to .C, by the end of .It calls on countries to move to sht to clean energy and accelerate efforts to phase down unabated coal power and inefficient fossil fuel subsidies.Read more: COP: Glasgow Pact watered down with last minute changesAnd it has measures on finance for poorer and more vulnerable countries to develop cleanly, cope with climate impacts and address the loss and damage they face from climate-related storms, floods, droughts and rising seas.There is also action on setting up carbon markets, and transparency on how countries report on their climate action.Why do we need this When the Paris Agreement was negotiated in , it was clear the national action plans, or nationally determined contributions , that countries had submitted for emissions cuts up to  left the world way off track to meet the temperature goals in the accord.So the agreement built in a ratchet mechanism that would see countrieswith updated plans up to  by Cop - which was meant to take place in , but was delayed by the pandemic.But the latest set of plans countries submitted in the run-up to Glasgow still leave the world for off track for the % emissions cuts needed by  to meet the .C goal, instead heading for .C of warming.Therefore, countries were under pressure to come up with a deal in Glasgow to take steps to rapidly increase their ambition for emission cuts in the s to stop the .C goal slipping out of reach.Read more: COP: Countries debate climate deal as summit heads into overtimeAnd with the impacts of .C of warming already biting, there was also pressure to provide the finance for developing countries to cope with the crisis, and to address the loss and damage they are facing.Will it succeed That remains to be seen. Action and pledges since the Paris climate summit have been bending the curve down towards less dangerous temperatures, but there is still a long way to go, and a very short time to do it.There is hope from the agreement that countries will come back with stronger action in the next year, and a signal that coal in particular is facing a bleak future.And a series of deals announced at Cop alongside the main negotiations - on cutting methane, switching to electric cars, protecting forests, driving finance towards green tech and actions and shting from coal to clean energy - may drive momentum,not deliver the scale of cuts needed on their own.What does it mean for ordinary people in the UK Not a huge amount in the short term.Lives are going to change because of climate action, but the UK already has targets to cut its emissions by % by , in line with the Paris Agreement, alongside its domestic legal carbon-cutting goals.It is implementing plans to meet them, with measures such as the coal power phaseout, conventional car ban and efforts to switch home heating to clean alternatives to boilers planned or under way.In the longer term, it keeps alive the possibility of limiting global warming to .C, helping protect people from the worst impacts of climate change.In the UK, that means avoiding the most damaging flooding and storms, coastal erosion, water shortages and heatwaves that rising temperatures will bring.In the words of the EUs Frans Timmermans, its about "avoiding a future for our children and grandchildren that is unliveable".

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessas we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive pound for two months offer here.From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ndash as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two monthshere.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ldquounsatisfactory on pollution, according to data from the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilcompanies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ldquovery poor in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ldquopoor.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandrsquos fish farms have been rated as ldquounsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentrsquos environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, wecan today reveal.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ldquovery poor, ldquopoor or ldquoat risk because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesacrossScotland that have been officiallydeemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencydamnedthe performance of more than  sitesincluding Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationrsquos protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inScotlandare in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandrsquos biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofhealthconditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.#Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadinghealthprofessionals ndash including consultants, GPs and medical academics ndash are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publictransportand green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandrsquos rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.New assessment methods used by the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ldquobad between  and . There are ldquosignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures, Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandrsquos most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ldquopoor, ldquovery poor or ldquoat risk, according to Scotlandrsquos environmental watchdog.Almost all these ldquounsatisfactory sites are considered to be among Scotlandrsquos critical national infrastructure ndash operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Read the full story here.Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ldquodisappointing picture of widespread failure on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.The Scottish Government must take ldquoradical action on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.

title: campbeltown-latest-area-receive-scottish-government-climate-funding
story: Campbeltown joins Alness, Annan, Blackburn, Holytown, Invergordon and Stevenston, with all the towns receiving pound, from the government.The Scottish Governmentrsquos Empowering Communities on Climate Action document stated: ldquoSeven towns have been chosen to help tackle the impact of climate change and secure a just transition to net zero.ldquoThe Climate Action Towns were chosen based on their population size , Scottish Index of Multiple Deprivationfactors and the fact they have historically not been engaged in climate action.ldquoThe Climate Action Towns programme will empower communities to come together and engage in collective climate action, taking account of the unique challenges and opportunities each town faces.ldquoThat might include looking at what action can be taken on switching to more sustainable food or renewable energy.ldquoCommunities in the seven towns will be offered support to find ways of making changes at a local level that will help tackle the crisis, giving them a voice and engaging those that may not have previously engaged in climate action.ldquoThe programme will be delivered by design agency Architecture and Design Scotland.:Nicola Sturgeon repeats call for Boris Johnson toto Glasgow and finish dealJust Transition Minister Richard Lochhead said: ldquoIt is clear that we must decarbonise industry and society in order to mitigate the worst effects of climate change, but we must do so in a way that is fair for everyone and leaves no-one behind.ldquoScotland was at the forefront of the Industrial Revolution, so we see it as only right that Scotland is at the forefront of this green revolution.ldquoWe have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to make changes in a way that will be good for our people, our communities, our economy and our planet ndash we must seize it.ldquoTackling the climate crisis requires all of us, at every level, to get involved. We can all make a dference.ldquoThe Climate Action Towns project aims to support and empower communities to have a say on how their local areas should change as part of a fair and just transition to net zero.ldquoI look forward to seeing how the towns that are taking part rise to the challenge and find ways that will not only make a dference locally but to Scotland and indeed the world.

title: bid to bring winter wonderland to kirkwall next week
story: featured newsBID to bring Winter Wonderland to Kirkwall next weekNovember ,  at : am vw, px"  Time to get your skates on! Kirkwall BID is bringing an ice rink to town, and much more merriment besides.It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas everywhere you go in Orkney, as businesses show off their festive fare in the run-up to Yuletide.In Kirkwall, it’s hoped that BID’s Winter Wonderland event will draw more folk to the street, with fun, food, shopping and skating all set to bring an added sparkle to the town centre.“From Thursday, November  to Monday, November , Kirkwall BID will be hosting a free skating rink and other festive attractions right here in the town centre,” said Kirkwall BID chairman, Duncan McLean.“It’s a dark and dreich time of year, so let BID bring some special sparkle, light and joy to the streets with a wonderful array of entertainments.“Next to the ice rink in Bridge Street car park, a rustic Alpine chalet will serve takeaway food and drinks with a skiing-lodge theme: bratwurst, churros, mulledcider and hot chocolate.“It’ll warm the cockles of your heart!”Meanwhile, the Saturday and Sunday are set to bring not only warmth to your heart, but to your stomach too!“Local food and drink producers will showcase their wares at a street market on Saturday, November  and Sunday, November ,” Mr McLean added.“Two special guests will be walking our streets — we can’t reveal their identity yet, but let’s just say they are warm-hearted but chilly sisters, you might say ‘frozen’. Other attractions will be revealed as we get closer to the weekend.“And throughout the town, shops, pubs and cafés will be bursting with festive treats, special offers, and of course Christmas gts and goodies.”Kirkwall BID is keen to emphasise that all activities have been planned and will be carried out with careful attention to the latest COVID advice from NHS Orkney. Everything BID organises over the weekend will take place outdoors, and safe distancing and frequent cleaning will be the order of the day.For more information on Winter Wonderland you can visit the Kirkwall BID Facebook page.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: big artefacts to go under cover at scapa flow museum
story: Sharp-eyed folk passing the Scapa Flow Visitor Centre and Museum at Lyness, next week, may see a rather unusual sight — big guns flying through the air!The two historic weapons, formerly attached to SMS Bremse and SMS Karlsruhe as part of the German High Seas Fleet, are being partially dismantled and lted from their outdoor plinths and brought under cover to await professional conservation.Nick Hewitt, OIC culture team leader will be there to keep a watchful eye.He said: #While we all love to see large objects outdoors, decades in a harsh marine environment have not been kind to these very important artefacts, which are two of only five First World War German naval guns surviving in the UK.“Both are now showing signs of the exposure, so it’s definitely time for them to come indoorswe want them to survive for another hundred years.“At the same time, we are also relocating the propeller from HMS Hampshire, which has since  been an imposing and much loved feature in the forecourt, to a more prominent position closer to the main vehicle entrance to the Museum # as well as the fuel filter equipment and the High Seas Fleet anchor.”Visitor Services Officer for the Museum, Jude Callister, said: “We will miss the presence of these big guns immensely but we are determined to secure dedicated funding for their repair and conservation and get them back on display as quickly as we can.“We’re confident as a team that the huge investment in the current Museum refurbishment and extension, which is now really taking shape, will help us leverage funding to get these extraordinary artefacts the care and expert work they need to protect and restore them.”The works, which are highly weather dependent, are planned for next week.Also being lted is a Hotchkiss gun from the deck of HMS Hampshire — one of  quick-firing-pounder Hotchkiss guns carried by the vessel. The gun will be taken out of storage where it has been for some time and carried to Kirkwall for an onward journey for conservation work by JPS Restoration, specialist large industrial conservators based in Alloa. The gun willto the county in the run up to Christmas to take up position inside the new Museum extension.The heavy lting and relocation work is being carried out by local firms Orkney Builders Contractors Ltd. and Heddle Construction Ltd., as part of the contract to refurbish the Museum’s Pumphouse and build the new extension.The guns from SMS Bremse and SMS Karlsruhe are both cm SK L – both these vessels were interned  with the rest of the High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow in , and scuttled by their own crews on  June . Bremse was salvaged by Ernest Cox ten years later, but Karlsruhe remains on the sea bed and is a popular site for recreational ers.SMS Bremse was a minelaying light cruiser launched in  in Stettin. She spent the war operating in the North Sea, taking part in a raid on British convoy to Norway in  which resulted in the sinking of two Royal Navy destroyers and nine merchant ships.SMS Karlsruhe was a light cruiser, launched in  in Kiel and named after the Imperial German Navy’s famous raiding cruiser which was lost in the Caribbean at the start of the First World War. She saw service in the North Sea and the Baltic. The gun from this vessel in the Museum’s collection is missing its gun shield.HMS Hampshire struck a German mine off Marwick Head in heavy weather on the evening of June , , and sank within  minutes. All but  men of over  on board perished, including Lord Kitchener, who was travelling with a delegation to Russia. Together the shaft plus the manganese bronze propellor weigh around  tons. They were removed from the wreck site in  by a German salvage ship. In , the shaft and propellor were ed to Orkney for display at the Scapa Flow Museum, with assistance at the time from Occidental Petroleum Flotta.The Scapa Flow Museum charts Orkney’s military involvement in the First and Second World Wars and provides a safe home for a major collection of wartime artefacts, many of national and international importance.It is currently undergoing a refurbishment project valued at of £. million, comprising an extension to the Museum and refurbishment of the historic pumphouse, supported by Orkney Islands Council, the National Lottery Heritage Fund, Historic Environment Scotland, the Orkney LEADER - programme, Highlands and Islands Enterprise, NatureScot and Museums Galleries Scotland.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: blues festival comeback postponed
story: coronavirusBlues Festival comeback postponedNovember ,  at : pmPlans by Orkney Blues Festival to bring a weekend of live music to Stromness, this November, have been postponed.The Blues Festival committee confirmed the decision, taken due to Orkney’s current situation with COVID-, this Wednesday evening.In a statement, the committee said: “After careful discussion and guidance, the Orkney Blues Festival committee has decided to postpone next week’s eventin light of the current COVID- situation within the county.“The health and safety of our community and festival attendees is our top priority and we feel it would be unwise to go ahead at the present time.“We aim to share a revised date with you very soon and all purchased tickets will be refunded. Please message the OBF Facebookyou have any queries.“As ever we thank you for your continued support of the festival and live music in Orkney.“Stay safe and we will see you all very soon.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
